locations.name: Aberlady
locations.description: A gang of 280 men hunted for the Provost of Edinburgh, here in 1556, hoping to kill him. The Sinclairs and Achesons of Gifford also fought here in 1565, with 1 man killed.

locations.name: Akeld
locations.description: Scots forces killed men here in 1297.

locations.name: Alnwick
locations.description: 16 reivers were executed here in 1528.

locations.name: Alnwick (Battle of)
locations.description: Many Scots were killed here in 1193, including King Malcolm III and his heir, Edward. Scotland's Queen Margaret also dies when she heard the news.

locations.name: Alston Moor
locations.description: Scottish reivers killed 3 men here in 1595.

locations.name: Amisfield
locations.description: Richard Latymer was hanged and quartered here in 1547.

locations.name: Ancrum
locations.description: William Kerr of Ancrum and others killed 2 burgesses of Jedburgh in 1572.

locations.name: Ancrum Moor
locations.description: Around 200 Englishmen were killed here, in 1545.

locations.name: Annan
locations.description: About 100 Scots were killed here in 1332, in a fight between Scottish supporters of the Bruces and the Balliols. The attack occurred at night time, forcing Edward Balliol to escape naked, on horseback. English reivers killed a man during a raid here in 1592. Another man was mutilated.

locations.name: Applegarth Town
locations.description: The Grahams killed 2 Jardines here in 1571.

locations.name: Appleby-in-Westmorland
locations.description: Richard Clifford of Appleby was known as “the butcher” for killing the Duke of York and his young son in 1460.

locations.name: Arkinholm
locations.description: The Douglases fought a pitched battle with King James II here in 1455. Archibald Douglas, Earl of Moray, was killed and his head presented to the king. His brother Hugh, Earl of Ormonde was also beheaded.

locations.name: Askerton Castle
locations.description: Rinion Armstrong was murdered here in 1597.

locations.name: Athelstaneford
locations.description: Local man George Hepburn was among 74 accused of killing John Geddes in 1568.

locations.name: Auchen Castle
locations.description: The owners (Kirkpatricks) of this castle were implicated in the murder of John Comyn in 1306.

locations.name: Auchencorth
locations.description: A Rutherford and Davidson were hanged for theft here in 1528.

locations.name: Bailey Head
locations.description: Lancie Armstrong killed a man and wounded a dozen others here in 1580.

locations.name: Bamburgh
locations.description: In 1597, the Scots broke into Sir John Foster’s house and tried to kill him but his wife managed to bolt the chamber door.

locations.name: Barholm
locations.description: The Browns of Carsluith Castle killed the Laird of Barholm in 1579.

locations.name: Barnhills Tower
locations.description: In 1502, the Turnbulls of Barnhills admitted various burnings and murders.

locations.name: Bassendean
locations.description: The Halls stole a horse here in 1510. Robert Hall was sentenced to be hanged.

locations.name: Bedrule
locations.description: 20 Turnbulls were fined at Jedburgh in 1502, for killing Robert Oliver. Two Turnbulls from here were acquitted of killing John Forbes in 1577.

locations.name: Belchester
locations.description: John Dixon of Belchester led a gang of 280 men, trying to kill Archibald Douglas in 1556.

locations.name: Bellingham
locations.description: Roger Fenwick, Keeper of Tynedale, was murdered here in 1537 “by three naughtie persons.” In 1596, the Elliots killed 3 men here and in 1597 the Scotts killed 3.

locations.name: Bemersyde
locations.description: The English commander Lord Evers died here in 1544, after the Battle of Ancrum Moor.

locations.name: Birkshaw
locations.description: Scottish reivers killed 4 men here in 1529.

locations.name: Berwick Road
locations.description: About 20 English soldiers died from drinking puddle water, on the way back from their great raids of 1542.

locations.name: Berwick-upon-Tweed
locations.description: English forces massacred thousands of townsfolk here in 1296, after Edward I ordered the mills to run with Scottish blood. In 1306, Nigel Bruce (brother of Robert) was hanged drawn and quartered here. In the siege of 1333, Edward III hanged 12 hostages at Hang-a-dyke Nook, in an attempt to force the authorities to surrender (the governor’s sons were 2 of the victims). In the siege of 1378 English forces killed the castle’s entire garrison apart from one man.

locations.name: Berwick-upon-Tweed
locations.description: The town witnessed many murders. For instance, Scottish assassins killed a man in 1592, before escaping. The Selbys also fought with the Grays in the churchyard, in 1596, with one dead and 4 or 5 gravely injured on each side.

locations.name: Berwick Walls
locations.description: Scottish reivers shot an English scout under the walls, in 1596.

locations.name: Bewcastle
locations.description: This town was the scene of many murders, thanks to its ties with notorious reivers. For instance, the Nixons and Crosers killed dozens of Lord Dacre’s men in 1528. The Armstrongs killed 7 men here in 1541. They also killed a man in 1583, cutting another man’s leg off in the process. The Scotts killed 3 men and a pregnant woman here in 1588 – and another man in 1595. The Armstrongs also killed men in 1592, 1596 and 1599 (in this case 3 men, after a day of “football and hard drinking”). The locals also inflicted losses, with at least one reiver killed in 1595.

locations.name: Blackadder
locations.description: John Hume of Blackadder and his brother were involved in the murder of David Falconer  around 1532. Several members of the Blackadder family were also murdered by the Humes around this time.

locations.name: Black Law
locations.description: The Armstrongs killed a man here one Midsummer in the 1570s.

locations.name: Blennerhasset
locations.description: Reivers killed several people here in 1592.

locations.name: Bloody Bush Road
locations.description: Some reivers were once killed here, at a place now known as the Bloody Bush.

locations.name: Blyth Bridge
locations.description: Thomas Burn was murdered here in 1493. The Flemings also killed a man here in 1545.

locations.name: Bonchester Bridge
locations.description: Peter Turnbull of Bonchester murdered James Rutherford at the Kirk of Hawick in 1502. At trial, Turnbull paid remission for a huge list of offences, spanning theft to burning.

locations.name: Bonshaw Tower
locations.description: 3 men were killed in a siege here in 1585, as the Maxwells tried to take the tower from the Irvings. They attacked it again in 1586.

locations.name: Brackenhill Tower
locations.description: Home of notorious reiver Richie Graham. Graham was personally responsible for at least 4 murders, among many crimes. He was even found to have a coin counterfeiter working here in 1596.

locations.name: Braidhaugh
locations.description: Thomas Dagliesh of Braidhaugh was hanged for receiving stolen horses in 1510.

locations.name: Brinkburn Priory and Manor House
locations.description: The Lisles (including 13 year old Humphrey Lisle, who would later become a notorious reiver) murdered the canon of Brinkburn here in 1521.

locations.name: Broomhouse
locations.description: A gang of Humes murdered the French diplomat Antoine De La Bastie and 4 other Frenchmen here, in 1517.

locations.name: Buccleuch
locations.description: Walter Scott AKA “the Bold Buccleuch” was guilty of 20 murders by his own hand according to Sir William Bowes in 1596. His men were accused of 50 murders.

locations.name: Buckholm
locations.description: 300 Armstrongs and Elliots sacked the tower here and murdered its owner George Hoppringle, in 1568.

locations.name: Burgh by Sands
locations.description: King Edward I died here in 1307, while waging war on the Scots.

locations.name: Caerlanrig
locations.description: King James V hanged between 36 and 48 members of the Armstrong clan (including the infamous Johnnie Armstrong of Gilnockie) at Caerlanrig in 1530.

locations.name: Caerlaverock
locations.description: English forces hanged 11 men from this area in 1548 - including Sir Herbert Maxwell, Vicar of Caerlaverock.

locations.name: Caerlaverock Castle
locations.description: Sir James Lindsay murdered Sir Roger Kirkpatrick here in 1357.

locations.name: Capon Tree Road
locations.description: Reivers were hanged on this road and their caps nailed to the tree, giving the road its name.

locations.name: Cardrona
locations.description: The Scotts of Tushielaw killed the owner of Cadrona here in 1601. Locals mutilated one of the Kerrs in 1608.

locations.name: Carham
locations.description: Many men – including 18 monks from the local monastery - were killed here in a battle between English and Scottish forces, in 1018. Scottish forces also fought here in 1377. The Pringles murdered a man during a revenge raid in 1596.

locations.name: Carlingwark Loch
locations.description: The Maxwells killed a man here in 1610.

locations.name: Carlisle
locations.description: The town was the scene of many executions. For instance, two of Robert the Bruce’s brothers were beheaded here in 1306. In 1323, Sir Andrew de Hercla was executed for aiding the Scots. In 1602, 6 reivers were executed for raiding the town and in 1605, 4 Grahams were executed for escaping prison. The town was also the scene of many murders – for instance the Grahams murdered one of their kin here in 1584 and also murdered someone here at Christmas 1599. In 1603, the Royal Commission ensured that 32 reivers were hanged, 15 banished and 140 outlawed.

locations.name: Carsluith
locations.description: The Browns of Carsluith murdered the Laird of Barholm as part of a religious feud, in 1579.

locations.name: Carter Fell
locations.description: The Croziers butchered Parcy Reed near here, around 1590. They rained 33 blows upon him, before dismembering him and throwing his limbs in the river, where his family collected them in pillow-cases.

locations.name: Castlemilk
locations.description: The Grahams tried to kill Robert Maxwell here in 1592.

locations.name: Catslack
locations.description: Sir James Douglas of Tortherwald killed Captain James Stewart here in 1596. Douglas was described in contemporary reports as “a man full of violence” and carried the head around on a lance, throughout the country. Dogs and pigs were also allowed to feed on the body before burial. Douglas himself was later killed by the Stewarts in 1613 on Edinburgh High St.

locations.name: Catslack Tower
locations.description: English forces burnt Elizabeth Scott and others alive here, in their 1548 raid on Catslack Tower.

locations.name: Caulside
locations.description: 3 or 4 Scots and 1 Englishman were killed near here in 1581, as reivers tried to escape with their plunder.

locations.name: Cessford Castle
locations.description: A gang from here murdered a man at Ford of Cale, in 1493, while stealing his horse, saddle, satchel, bow and purse. Sir Robert Kerr of Cessford was personally accused of 8 murders in 1596 alone, probably 16 in total.

locations.name: Chattlehope Burn
locations.description: 3 reivers were killed in a fight here.

locations.name: Chatton
locations.description: Scottish reivers killed Richard Reveley of Chatton  in 1595.

locations.name: Cherrytrees
locations.description: James Tait of Kelso was charged with murder here in 1605 with his accomplices “armed with swords, steel bonnets, lances and pistols.”

locations.name: Chipchase Castle
locations.description: Several Scottish reivers were killed in a raid here, in 1528. Sir John Heron killed Roger Fenwick in 1537, as part of an ongoing feud. In 1575, Sir George Heron was murdered in the notorious clash at Redeswire.

locations.name: Chillingham Castle
locations.description: 8 members of the Grey family were executed for high treason.

locations.name: Chirnside
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1497 and 1565 “with some slaughter”

locations.name: Closeburn
locations.description: The Johnstones raided this place in 1585, during a spree which took 18 lives. In 1611, Alexander Kilpatrick murdered James Carmichael here.

locations.name: Cockburnspath
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1532, with the help of rebels like Alexander Hume (who was later beheaded).

locations.name: Cockermouth
locations.description: A man was killed by the wheel of his own cart, during a raid to arrest reivers in 1605.

locations.name: Cocklaw Tower
locations.description: John Gledstone of Cocklaw was charged with 2 murders in 1561

locations.name: Cockpen
locations.description: George Broune of Cockpen was hanged here in 1610, for stealing horses from Newbattle park.

locations.name: Coldingham Priory
locations.description: In 1420, the prior burnt some reivers alive, while trying to remove them from the church. Two later priors were murdered here, in 1518 (David Hume) and 1519 (Robert Blackadder).

locations.name: Colwell
locations.description: Reivers killed 2 men from here in 1582.

locations.name: Congalton House
locations.description: Henry Congalton of Congalton killed Oliver Congalton by poisoning him in 1554. The same year, Henry and 5 others attacked William Chirnside in his home. Chirnside wounded Congalton “to the effusion of his blood” and killed one of his men. Henry Conglaton was one of many men implicated in the murder of John Geddes in 1565.

locations.name: Conheath
locations.description: Robert Maxwell of Conheath was murdered by 3 men in 1530 and then his brother James murdered John Chalmer, before going on the run.

locations.name: Copshaw
locations.description: John Elliot of Copshaw famously wounded the Earl of Bothwell in 1566, before being killed himself.

locations.name: Corbet Tower House
locations.description: John Rutherford killed Andrew Kerr of Corbet house in 1558, sparking a 2 year feud.

locations.name: Corsbie Tower
locations.description: In 1609, the Cranstouns and Frenches shot pistols at each other. Then in 1612, Johnne Cranstoun was murdered by the Frenches (their leader was beheaded). Gilbert Cranstoun of Corsbie was hanged the same year, for various reiving offences and feuding.

locations.name: Covington
locations.description: The Douglases killed a man here in 1494.

locations.name: Cowdenknowes
locations.description: John Hume of Cowdenknowes was a very violent man. In 1537, he and a gang of 120 men waylaid the Abbott of Melrose. In 1552, he killed “Wicked” Wat Scott in Edinburgh. In 1554, he killed a Fenchman and brutally wounded another at Newbattle. In 1565 he was one of the leaders of 1,000 Humes, who raided the Kerrs of Ferniehurst and in 1569 his sons killed John Haitlie of Mellerstain.

locations.name: Crawford
locations.description: The Bells and Armstrongs killed 2 men here in 1585.

locations.name: Crichton Castle
locations.description: 16 Crichtons were killed in a bloody feud with the Johstones in the 1500s.

locations.name: Dalfibble
locations.description: The Maxwells killed several Johnstones here in 1602.

locations.name: Dalhousie Castle
locations.description: Nicholas Ramsay killed his brother George here in 1526. Nicholas Ramsay then killed Patrick Henry and was himself beheaded in 1555.

locations.name: Dally
locations.description: According to legend, the daughter of the Dally Castle owner fell in love with their enemy, Gilbert, and her brother killed him at Gib’s Cross.

locations.name: Dalveen Pass
locations.description: The Johnstones killed a man here in 1597.

locations.name: Darlington
locations.description: Scottish forces attacked this place in 1322 and 1327 (with several killed).

locations.name: Debatable Land
locations.description: This was the scene of countless murders. So much so that, in an effort to root out the culprits, the Scottish and English governments combined in 1537 and 1551, to declare that anybody could kill the inhabitants here, rob them or burn their houses, without legal consequence.

locations.name: Denwick
locations.description: Scottish reivers stole all the village’s horses in 1596. The locals recovered them and killed the reiver leader – an infamous fellow named James Burne – with a shot in the back.

locations.name: Dilston
locations.description: The notorious reiver Hob Elwold was executed here in 1531, after being apprehended by the even more notorious Humphrey Lisle.

locations.name: Dirleton
locations.description: David Falcoun (Captain of the KIng's Footmen) was killed here in 1528 (probably by the Douglases).

locations.name: Dinwoodie Mains
locations.description: Thomas Dinwoodie was murdered here in 1504. That same year, Nicholas Dinwoodie was hanged for his own violent crimes and Robert Dinwoodie was convicted of theft. In 1508 Patrick Dinwoodie was hanged for murdering the laird of Glendinning. In 1583, Robert Maxwell was killed here, by 3 other Maxwells.

locations.name: Dolphinston
locations.description: Two men from here killed Sir William Colvile of Ochiltree in 1509.

locations.name: Donkleywood
locations.description: The Scotts killed 35 people in this area (including 7 burnt alive) in 1597. It was the 3rd time Scottish reivers had raided the area in a week. Scott of Buccleuch claimed it was in response to Tynedale men killing 2 Scots and blamed the “obstinate” locals for being burnt alive, as they should have trusted him and opened their doors.

locations.name: Drawdykes
locations.description: The Carletons killed the owner of Drawdykes Castle in 1599.

locations.name: Dreva on Tweed
locations.description: Adam Tweedy of Dreva mutilated Robert Rammage by cutting his ears off in 1565.

locations.name: Drumburgh
locations.description: The Armstrongs raided this place in 1602. The locals tracked the culprits, burnt the door of their tower and killed the ringleader.

locations.name: Drumelzier
locations.description: The Tweedies of Drumelzier were an extremely violent family. They murdered Sir John Fleming in 1534 and William Geddes in 1559. In 1565, they cut the ears off a man called Robert Rammage. The next year, they were implicated in the murder of David Rizzio at Holyroodhouse. They then killed the Provost of Peebles in 1572, “many” reivers at Riskinhope in 1587 and Patrick Veitch at Peebles 1590. Finally, they killed James Geddes in Edinburgh, in 1592 and Walter Scott of Tushielaw in 1612.  They were still cited as being involved in various feuds, in 1621.

locations.name: Drumlanrig
locations.description: The Earl of Angus hanged some hostages here in 1548.

locations.name: Drumlanrig's Tower
locations.description: James Douglas of Drumlanrig killed the rector of Kirkbride in 1543. Drumlanrig’s bother killed William Dalziel in 1555. 2 Johnstones were killed on a raid here, in 1597.

locations.name: Dryfe Sands
locations.description: Over 700 feuding Maxwells and Johnstones were killed here, in 1593.

locations.name: Dryhope
locations.description: A local reiver named Howloose was killed by the English Warden's posse near here in 1584.

locations.name: Dryhope Tower
locations.description: Dickie Dryhope was a notorious reiver who was responsible for many killings, including a pregnant woman.

locations.name: Dumfries
locations.description: This place was the scene of many infamous murders. Most notoriously, Robert the Bruce stabbed John and Richard Comyn to death at the altar of Greyfriars Church in 1306. In 1504, Robert Grersoune killed a chaplain here. In 1587, Archibald McBrair killed Archibald Newall (and was sent to Edinburgh to be beheaded). In 1596, the notorious reiver Johnne Carruthers shot a man dead here. In 1608, Lord Maxwell murdered Lord Johnstone, as part of their long feud (he was later beheaded in Edinburgh). And in 1613, another Maxwell (“Achilles John”) killed a man with 2 blows to the head and 30 to the body.

locations.name: Dumfries - executions
locations.description: Dumfries was also used as a place of execution. Robert the Bruce’s brother-in-law was hanged, drawn and quartered here in 1306. In 1504, the reivers Gilbert Thomsone and Adam Baty were hanged here. In 1602, over 30 reivers were hanged -and another 32 in 1603 (prompting the townsfolk to turn on the authorities and hack their way out). There wee also mass hangings in 1609.

locations.name: Dunbar
locations.description: 2 men were hanged for trying to break out prisoners from the castle in 1512. English forces killed 12 men here in 1544. Sir John Howdene, the chaplain of Dunbar killed a man in 1553 and tried to kill 4 more in 1554.

locations.name: Duncow
locations.description: The Johnstones killed a man here in 1585, during their feud with Maxwells.

locations.name: Duns
locations.description: 4 men mutilated Hugh Lauder here in 1554 (in retaliation for Robert Lauder mutilating one of them a month before). George Stephenson was abducted by the Humes of Red Braes and taken back here to be executed in 1596.

locations.name: Eccles
locations.description: English forces killed 8 men in the abbey here, in 1544.

locations.name: Eckford
locations.description: English forces killed 34 people here in 1544.

locations.name: Ednam
locations.description: James Pilmure murdered 2 men here in 1494.

locations.name: Edinburgh - Blackfriars
locations.description: Lord Bothwell killed William Stewart here in 1586.

locations.name: Edinburgh - Blackfriars Wynd
locations.description: Up to 80 Hamiltons were killed at the top of Blackfriars Street by the Douglases in 1520, an event known as “Cleanse the causeway”.

locations.name: Edinburgh - Boroughmuir
locations.description: The reiver Lyell Hall was hanged at Borougmuir in 1563. The body of Thomas Armstrong was hanged in chains here, in 1601.

locations.name: Edinburgh Castle
locations.description: The Earl of Douglas and his young brother were murdered here at the infamous “Black Dinner’ in 1440. English forces killed over 500 Scots here in 1544.

locations.name: Edinburgh - Castlehill
locations.description: Many Border lords and reivers were executed on Castle Hill or in the Grassmarket. For instance, 10 Border men were executed here for sheepstealing and murder in 1512. Lord Home and his brother William were executed here in 1516 (in 1520 their brother George stole the heads from the Tolbooth in a night raid). Adam Scott, “The King of Thieves”, was beheaded here in 1530. George Scott “of the Bog” was stripped naked and burnt here in 1532. 6 reivers were hanged here in 1562, while their associates were drowned in Hawick. Another 5 were hanged in in 1564, including Hob “Colyfurd” Scott, John “the Clerk” Scot and Mark Elliot “of the Hill”. In 1598, the Laird of Johnstone was hanged upside down in chains for murdering various Maxwells in their long-running feud (Lord Maxwell was later beheaded for murdering Sir James Johnstone). Thomas Armstrong was hanged in 1600, for the murder of Sir John Carmichael. Two more Armstrongs and an Irving were hanged in 1612.

locations.name: Edinburgh - Cowgate
locations.description: The Tweedys of Drumelzier were involved in many Border feuds which spilled over into Edinburgh. For instance, in 1498, the Cockburns mutilated Andrew Tweedy here. Then in 1563, three men from Polmude killed James Tweedy, as he slept by the fire. In 1590, the Veitches murdered John Tweedy. The Tweedys got some revenge by shooting an accomplice of the Veitches in the Cowgate, in 1592.

locations.name: Edinburgh - Craigmillar Castle
locations.description: This castle was the centre of a plot (The Craigmillar Bond) to murder Lord Darnley, in 1566.

locations.name: Edinburgh - Grassmarket
locations.description: In 1581, James Douglas, Earl of Morton, was beheaded in the Grassmarket, in relation to the murder of Lord Darnley.

locations.name: Edinburgh - High St
locations.description: The Kerrs murdered Sir Walter Scott (an ancestor of the writer) on the High Street in 1552, as part of their long-running Border feud.

locations.name: Edinburgh - Holyroodhouse
locations.description: Several Borders lords were involved in the murder of David Rizzio in 1566.

locations.name: Edinburgh - Kirk O' Field
locations.description: Lord Darnley was murdered here (probably strangled after an explosion did not kill him) in 1567. The Borders aristocrat Bothwell was the likeliest culprit, although he was acquitted.

locations.name: Edinburgh - Old Mercat Cross
locations.description: Thomas Armstrong had his hand cut off here, before being hanged in 1601, for the murder of Sir John Carmichael.

locations.name: Edinburgh - Old Tolbooth
locations.description: The heads of the Hume brothers were displayed here in 1516. A few years later, one of the remaining brothers liberated the skulls, with the help of the Douglases and took them away for burial. The Tweedies of Drumelzier also murdered Sir John Fleming here in 1534

locations.name: Edinburgh - St Giles
locations.description: Gordon of Lochinvar murdered Thomas McLellan on the steps of the cathedral in 1526, as part of a Galloway feud.

locations.name: Egremont
locations.description: 3 reivers from here were executed in 1605.

locations.name: Elishaw
locations.description: Scottish reivers killed two men here in 1582.

locations.name: Elsdon
locations.description: Reivers killed 14 men here in a raid in 1584. Hundreds of skeletons from the Battle of Otterburn were discovered in the church of St Cuthberts during restoration works in the 1800s.

locations.name: Eskdale
locations.description: English reivers killed 3 men here in 1583.

locations.name: Eslington
locations.description: Sir Cuthbert Collingwood killed a member of the Burns gang as they committed a raid here in 1587. His men also captured and hanged 40-50 members of the raiding party. This sparked a long feud which left 35 Collingwoods killed and forced Sir Cuthbert to leave his house.

locations.name: Etal
locations.description: English forces killed 25 Scots here in 1523

locations.name: Etal Castle
locations.description: John Manners killed William Heron here in 1428, as he besieged the castle as part of an ongoing feud. After arbitration by the church, Manners agreed to pay for 500 Masses for Heron’s soul and give 250 Marks to his widow.

locations.name: Ettrick Forest
locations.description: Sir William Douglas murdered his godfather (also Sir William Douglas, the notorious “knight of Liddesdale”) here in 1353.

locations.name: Eyemouth
locations.description: The English navy landed and killed 5 people here in 1542.

locations.name: Fairnington
locations.description: English forces killed about 200 Scots here in 1549: the last major victory for the longbow.

locations.name: Falahill
locations.description: John Murray was murdered here in 1510, by 5 Scott brothers and Andrew Kerr.

locations.name: Falstone
locations.description: Some men were murdered here around 1371.

locations.name: Fa'side Castle
locations.description: English forces burnt this tower in 1547, killing everyone within.

locations.name: Fauldshope
locations.description: James Gray of Fauldshope and 1 other killed Anthony Tait while stealing 160 sheep in 1502. At trial, Gray paid remission for this and many other crimes, including the theft of another 240 sheep.

locations.name: Featherstone
locations.description: A gang of Ridleys murdered Sir Albany Featherstonehaugh here in 1530.

locations.name: Felkington
locations.description: The Kerrs killed 3 Englishmen here in 1533, during a large raid.

locations.name: Ferniehirst Castle
locations.description: 30 Scots and 4 English were killed here in 1523. The Earl of Surrey said the Scots were “The boldest and hottest men that ever I saw in any nation”. Scottish forces slaughtered 130 men of the English garrison in 1549, including the commander who had his head sliced off with one blow, so that it landed 4 paces away.

locations.name: Flodden Field
locations.description: More than 11,000 men were killed here in 1513, the vast majority of them Scots, in the nation's worst-ever defeat.

locations.name: Ford Castle
locations.description: In 1388, the Lilburns slaughtered the entire garrison of this castle. During 1557-58, three men were killed here as a result of a feud between the Herons and the Carrs.

locations.name: Gamescleuch
locations.description: Simon Scott built this tower in 1570 but never moved in as his mother-in-law poisoned him on the eve of his marriage to her daughter.

locations.name: Gateshaw
locations.description: Andrew Kerr of Gateshaw and 5 Scott brothers killed John Murray of Falahill in 1510.

locations.name: Gifford
locations.description: 6 Gifford men killed John Sinclair in Aberlady in 1565. The Sinclairs came back and wounded a man in revenge.

locations.name: Gilsland
locations.description: English chroniclers claimed that Scottish forces burnt 200 men, women and children here in 1389 although this is likely to be an exaggeration. In 1596, a gang of Scottish reivers combined to attack Thomas Carleton’s house with long ladders, to avenge his killing of a family member in 1594. Christopher Bell was later executed after confessing to 11 murders (but he was likely framed by Thomas Carleton. In 1598, a gang of Ogles broke into a house here in 1598, and murdered David Elliot (who was hiding here, after killing one of their family in a previous attack). Thomas Carleton was killed trying to apprehend the Ogles.

locations.name: Gogar
locations.description: During the Ruthven Conspiracy of 1600, the Erskines of Gogar killed 2 of the Ruthvens.

locations.name: Goldielands Tower
locations.description: The last occupant was said be hanged from his own gateway for stealing cattle.

locations.name: Gordon
locations.description: 3 men from here killed Andrew Redpath of Greenlaw in 1538.

locations.name: Greenhaugh
locations.description: A gang of 300 Scotts killed 4 Charltons here in 1595 (and promised to come back for more).

locations.name: Greenlaw
locations.description: 3 men from Gordon killed Andrew Redpath of Greenlaw in 1538.

locations.name: Greenlaw Dean
locations.description: Stevin Brounfield the young Laird of Greenlawdene was murdered here in 1564.

locations.name: Grubbit
locations.description: Thomas Middlemas was slain by Peter Pott and Jock Pott “the bastard” at Grubbit in 1596.

locations.name: Harelaw
locations.description: The Armstrongs of Harelaw kidnapped 4 Hendersons in 1601, killing the eldest of them, to encourage the family to pay up.

locations.name: Hadden
locations.description: As many as 2,000 men (mostly English) were killed in the Battle of Hadden Rig in 1542.

locations.name: Haddington
locations.description: the Duke of Atholl was murdered here in 1242, after a jousting argument. William Newton killed John Crumming here in 1545 as part of an ancient feud. About 200 Englishmen were killed here in 1548. The Earl of Bothwell also wounded John Cockburn of Ormiston here in 1559, after a sword fight. He then took £1000 that Cockburn was bringing from England, to fight the French.

locations.name: Haddington - St Mary's
locations.description: The parish clerk George Bald killed a man here in 1553.

locations.name: Haggerston
locations.description: Scottish reivers killed a man here in 1602.

locations.name: Halidon Hill Battlefield
locations.description: Over 3,000 Scots were killed here in 1333.

locations.name: Haltwhistle
locations.description: The Armstrongs engaged in a deadly feud with the Ridleys in 1570. They also killed a man here in 1599.

locations.name: Hassendean
locations.description: The Elliots killed the Laird of Hassendean in 1564.

locations.name: Haughton Castle
locations.description: This castle is said to be haunted by the reiver Archie Armstrong, who starved to death in its dungeon.

locations.name: Hawick
locations.description: 8 men (mostly Scotts) were accused of killing John Elliot in the kirkyard here and hanging him from the steeple in 1612. They successfully argued that he had killed himself.

locations.name: Hawick - River Teviot
locations.description: Up to 40 reivers were executed in a mass drowning here, in 1562 (the method chosen because of “a lack of trees and halters’). A further 11 reivers were hanged and 7 drowned here in 1567.

locations.name: Haydon Bridge
locations.description: Sir George Heron ambushed a gang of Scots reivers in 1587, killing 6 of them and taking 16 horses. He was later accused of allowing the raid to happen, so he could take the spoils.

locations.name: Headshaw
locations.description: Thomas Scott of Headshaw killed John Murray of Falahill in 1510.

locations.name: Heavyside
locations.description: Robert Hall of Heavyside was hanged in 1510 for a long list of reiving offences.

locations.name: Hell Beck
locations.description: Queen Elizabeth's forces killed 300-400 rebels here in 1570.

locations.name: Henderland
locations.description: The Cockburns murdered Roger and Walter Tweedy here in 1498. In 1530, William Cockburn was arrested on numerous charges of theft, slaughter and abetting the English. Legend has it that he was hanged over his own gate and his wife ran to a nearby waterfall so she could not hear his death throes. But it seems he was actually beheaded in Edinburgh and his head placed on the tolbooth there.

locations.name: Herdmanston Mains
locations.description: The Sinclairs of Herdmanston slaughtered Walter Murray here in 1565.

locations.name: Hermitage Castle
locations.description: Sir William de Soulis murdered Sir Alexander Armstrong here, in 1320. Legend has it that he was boiled in lead but this is not true (he died a prisoner at Dumbarton Castle). Sir William Douglas killed his former friend, Sir Alexander Ramsay, here in 1338, by starving him to death. The Earl of Bothwell was shot here by John Elliott in 1566 (Elliott was later killed). Bothwell later murdered Lord Darnley so that he could marry Mary Queen of Scots.

locations.name: Hermitage Water
locations.description: A Henderson murdered his kinsman here in 1538 and was hanged.

locations.name: Hethersgill
locations.description: Hethersgill - locals chased off some reivers here in 1584 and killed one.

locations.name: Hethpool
locations.description: Scottish reivers killed a man here in 1596 and left another in peril of death.

locations.name: Houndwood
locations.description: A gang of 10 men led by Sir Patrick Hepburne of Waughton killed Robert Broun near here in 1615.

locations.name: Horsburgh Castle
locations.description: The Horsburghs murdered men here in 1603 and 1608 (and were sentenced to die). In 1611, they were attacked in Peebles by the Scotts. The Horsburghs were also involved in armed attacks of their own in 1610, 1611, 1615, 1616 (including an attack in Leith) and 1625.

locations.name: Humbleton
locations.description: Thousands of Scots died here in a bloody battle of 1402. In Henry IV, Shakespeare described the carnage as “ten thousand bold Scots, two and twenty knights, balked in their own blood.”

locations.name: Hume Castle
locations.description: A Spanish mercenary was killed here in 1548 during a failed mutiny of the garrison, against the English occupiers. The Humes later killed the garrison in their beds. Two English rebels were executed here in 1570. In 1606, Lord Hume hanged 140 reivers in September alone, having turned to working for the crown.

locations.name: Hunthill
locations.description: John Rutherford of Hunthill murdered Andrew Kerr of Corbet house in 1558, sparking a 2 year feud. In 1597, the English complained that the Rutherfords were harbouring a dozen English outlaws and that together they had murdered and robbed hundreds of people south of the border.

locations.name: Inchkeith
locations.description: English forces landed here in 1522, drowned people and wasted the area.

locations.name: Innerwick Castle
locations.description: English forces slaughtered the entire garrison here, in 1547.

locations.name: Jedburgh
locations.description: The English keeper of Jedburgh was killed in a duel with his Scottish counterpart, in 1394. The Kerrs killed a chaplain here in 1494. King James IV personally oversaw a mass hanging of reivers here in 1510. An actor (stage player) was killed in 1516. Also 10 English soldiers were killed here in 1523 after burning the town.

locations.name: Jedforest
locations.description: Reivers killed Thomas Henrison here in 1493 and stole 5 ewes.

locations.name: Kale Water
locations.description: A gang of Kerrs murdered a man here in 1493, robbing him of his horse, saddle, satchel, bow and purse.

locations.name: Kelso
locations.description: The Olivers murdered 2 men here 1502. Peter Nairne was charged with inducing several Englishmen to cross the border, with the aim of killing them in 1601.

locations.name: Kelso Abbey
locations.description: Kelso Abbey - in 1545, the English forces (aided by Spanish mercenaries) destroyed the abbey and killed everybody within it. The abbot was slain by his relation (Kerr of Cessford) in 1566.

locations.name: Kershope
locations.description: The Olivers killed 2 men here in 1502.

locations.name: Kershopefoot
locations.description: Three men (Lilburn, Starhead and “the bastard” Heron) killed the Scottish warden Robert Kerr here at a truce day in 1508. Kerr’s confederates tracked down Lilburn to York and brought his head back to Scotland in a sack.

locations.name: Kilham
locations.description: The Kerrs killed Thomas Storey killed here in 1596 (after the Storeys had killed one of their shepherds). Scottish reivers killed another man here in 1597.

locations.name: Kirkbride
locations.description: James Douglas of Drumlanrig killed the rector of Kirkbride, in 1543.

locations.name: Kirkharle
locations.description: The reiver Robert Loraine was ambushed on his way back from church in 1483, and his body cut into pieces “small as flesh for the pot” and stuffed into his saddlebags. Then his horse was sent home, as a message to his family. A statue marks the spot of his murder.

locations.name: Kirk Yetholm
locations.description: English forces killed some men here in 1544.

locations.name: Lag Tower
locations.description: The Jonstones raided this place in 1585, during a spree which cost 18 lives.

locations.name: Lamington
locations.description: The Douglases killed 1 man and maimed 6 in 1588.

locations.name: Lanehead
locations.description: The notorious thief Jemmy Dodd of Burnmouth and five accomplices were caught reiving in England and all six hanged in Newcastle in 1523 (two others escaped after a party of 80 reivers intervened).

locations.name: Langholm
locations.description: The authorities killed 30 Armstrongs here in 1524 and another 32 in 1532.

locations.name: Langton
locations.description: Robert Dougal and Thomas Broune of Langton were both beheaded in 1493, for the slaughter of Thomas Aitchison. The Cockburns of Langton helped kill the French diplomat Antoine De la Bastie in 1517.

locations.name: Lauder
locations.description: William Lauder of Lauder was beheaded in 1549 for assisting the English in 1547. A prisoner was lynched and killed here, by the Humes and Cranstouns, in 1598.

locations.name: Leaplish
locations.description: Reivers shot 3 women here in 1611, killing one of them.

locations.name: Leith
locations.description: Over 1,000 people were killed in fighting in 1560, during the siege of Leith.

locations.name: Learmouth
locations.description: Scottish forces killed a woman here in 1523.

locations.name: Lessudden
locations.description: English forces killed several men here in 1544.

locations.name: Levens Bridge
locations.description: Ritchie Graham murdered George Graham here in 1502.

locations.name: Liddel Strength
locations.description: Scottish forces killed the Royal Constable, Walter Selby, here in 1346, after forcing him to watch his two sons being strangled. Over 40 Englishmen were also killed.

locations.name: Liddisdale
locations.description: The Earl of Angus killed over 30 reivers here in 1527. The local reivers killed 11 English pursuers in 1528. Scotts killed 7 Elliots and Croziers here in 1564. In 1596, the people of Liddesdale were accused of murdering 50 English people “in recent years.” That year, Lord Scrope’s English forces killed 2 men and up to 10 infants.

locations.name: Lincluden
locations.description: William Douglas of Lincluden was a notorious reiver who was found guilty of a long list of raids and murders in 1610. He was sentenced to have his right hand cut off, then to be hanged, but this was later commuted to banishment from Scotland. He crept back in 1612.

locations.name: Lintalee
locations.description: John Henrison was murdered here in 1493, as reivers stole 6 ewes.

locations.name: Linton
locations.description: George Kerr of Linton and 13 others killed 2 reivers named Hall, who had raided them months earlier in 1537. A mass grave, with more than 50 skulls, was found here in 1792.

locations.name: Lochmaben
locations.description: The Johnsones killed Captain Oliphant and various others who had been sent to capture them here in 1585, before setting fire to the parish church. The Maxwells attacked the Johnstones here in 1585. The Armstrongs murdered Sir John Carmichael here in 1600.

locations.name: Lochrutton
locations.description: The Laird of Auchenfranko was killed here in 1543.

locations.name: Lochwood Castle
locations.description: The Armstrongs killed 8 people here in 1545. The Maxwells killed 6 men here in 1585.

locations.name: Lockerbie
locations.description: One of the Earl of Morton’s men was killed here in 1585 and 4 Johnstones were hanged from the walls. Scores of Maxwells were slaughtered in the streets here by the Johnstones, giving rise to the expression a “Lockerbie lick”, for a gash across the face.

locations.name: Macbiehill
locations.description: John Hamilton was murdered here in 1591.

locations.name: Makerstoun
locations.description: Thomas Macdowell of Makerston and 13 others killed 2 reivers named Hall, who had raided them months earlier in 1537.

locations.name: Mangerton Tower
locations.description: Hector Armstrong killed Barty Young for leading the English to the castle in 1543.

locations.name: Manslaughter Law
locations.description: There was a bloody fight near here in 1402, between the Earl of Dunbar and the Hepburns. The site is now called Manslaughter Law.

locations.name: Maxton
locations.description: The Olivers killed John Moffat here in 1502. John Faulo killed and robbed David Henrison here in 1502.

locations.name: Mellerstain
locations.description: The Humes killed Alexander Hailie of Mellerstain in 1569. Another Laird of Mellerstain was murdered by the Humes in 1603, as a result of a long-running feud.

locations.name: Melrose
locations.description: Scottish forces killed or captured about 80 members of the Berwick garrison near here, in 1316. English forces killed 4 monks here in 1322, including the prior. The Humes tried to murder the abbot in 1537.

locations.name: Melrose Skirmish Hill
locations.description: Nearly 200 Scotts, Douglases and Kerrs were killed at Skirmish Hill in 1526, sparking a decades-long feud. Some were hanged including James Elwald.

locations.name: Merse
locations.description: English forces killed about 400 Scots in this area, in 1544.

locations.name: Middleton Hall
locations.description: The Rutherfords killed a man here in 1596.

locations.name: Milfield
locations.description: Up to 600 Scots and 60 English were killed here in 1513, when a huge raiding party led by Lord Hume was ambushed by Sir William Bulmer.

locations.name: Mindrum
locations.description: Nicholas Bolton of Mindrum was slain at his own plough by the Kerrs in 1596.

locations.name: Minto
locations.description: William and Archibald Turnbull of Minto murdered John Rutherford in 1499. Andrew Turnbull killed a man in 1580 but was spared hanging as he was of a young age.

locations.name: Moffat
locations.description: The Jardines killed a man and his daughter near here, in 1584. They killed 2 more people and were sent to Edinburgh Castle, only to escape.

locations.name: Morton Castle
locations.description: The Earl of Morton was executed in 1580, for his part in the murder of Lord Darnley.

locations.name: Moss Tower
locations.description: English forces killed 34 men here in 1545.

locations.name: Mouswald
locations.description: Reivers killed the Laird of Mouswald in 1504. Lord Herries killed a later laird in 1548.

locations.name: Mungo's Walls
locations.description: Andrew Blackadder of Mungo’s Walls murdered John and Phillip Nesbitt in 1499.

locations.name: Naworth Castle
locations.description: The castle contains an oak tree, from which Lord Howard is said to have hanged 63 Armstrongs in 2 years.

locations.name: Neidpath Castle
locations.description: The Tweedys killed a member of the Veitch clan here, in 1590, during their bloody feud. A duel was fought here in 1592, with a man nearly killed.

locations.name: Newbattle
locations.description: George Broune of Cockpen was hanged here in 1610, for stealing horses from Newbattle park.

locations.name: Newbie
locations.description: Reivers killed a man and a 2-year-old infant here in 1508. The culprits were drawn and hanged. Many dead bodies and swords were also discovered here - probably from the Battle of Annan.

locations.name: Newbiggin
locations.description: Peter Hall committed several murders and thefts here in 1493.

locations.name: Newcastle upon Tyne
locations.description: 16 Scots were executed here in 1306. 6 reivers including Jemmy Dodd of Burnmouth were hanged here in 1523. Sir William Lisle, John Ogle, William Shaftoe and Thomas Fenwick (“all bandits”) killed their gaolers and escaped from prison here in 1527. They then went on a year-long crime spree before being recaptured and eexecuted in 1528. 10 Grahams were executed here 1605. . A further 17 reivers were executed that year (4 of them Scots).

locations.name: Newlands
locations.description: Charles Lowry killed Walter Newlands of Newlands in 1526.

locations.name: Niddrie
locations.description: The Earl of Bothwell killed 50 of the king’s men here in 1592.

locations.name: Nisbet
locations.description: There were 2 battles on this site. In 1355, Scottish forces beat the English. A French knight bought the prisoners and killed them all, in revenge for the death of his father. The local landmark “Slaughter hill” marks the spot. In 1402, English forces defeated the Scots. The Scottish leader Sir Patrick Hepburn was among the dead.

locations.name: Nithsdale
locations.description: The Johnstones killed 18 people in this area in 1595.

locations.name: Norham Castle
locations.description: The captain of Norham Castle was killed at the battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545.

locations.name: North Berwick
locations.description: John Matheson was beheaded in 1537 for various murders in the town and siding with the traitor Douglases. The prioress of North Berwick was involved in a violent dispute with Alexander Oliphant in 1550.

locations.name: Old Woodhouselee
locations.description: This tower was owned by James Hamilton, who holds the dubious honour of being the first person in world history to assassinate somebody (Regent Morton, in 1570) with a firearm.

locations.name: Ormiston (Roxburghshire)
locations.description: James and Hob Ormeston were among the murderers of Darnley in 1567 and were executed in 1573 in Edinburgh. While awaiting execution James also confessed to the murder of Michael Hunter and hanging another man “in a rage” plus “mony other wickit deids”. The Kerrs of Ormeston also tried to kill some of Robert Carey’s men at Norham in 1596.

locations.name: Otterburn
locations.description: About 2,000 Scots and English were killed here in 1388. Scottish reivers also killed a man here in 1582.

locations.name: Ovingham
locations.description: The Abbot of Hexham was hanged here after defying orders to dissolve the abbey in 1535.

locations.name: Pawston
locations.description: Reivers killed John Selby here in 1596, as he tried to protect his cattle.

locations.name: Peebles
locations.description: Many families took part in deadly feuds here. The Bruces and Comyns fought each other in 1299. George Dickson murdered Simon Dickson in 1502. George Tweedy killed William Young in 1510. Dutho Stewart was beheaded for murdering Thomas Forester in 1550. The Tweedies killed John Dickson in 1572 and Patrick Veitch in 1590, prompting the Veitches to kill John Tweedy in Edinburgh. In 1603, the Horsburghs murdered a man and were sentenced to die.

locations.name: Pinkie Cleugh
locations.description: Thousands of Scots were killed here in 1547, with only 250 English losses.

locations.name: Piperdean
locations.description: Around 1,700 Scots and English were killed here, at the Battle of Piperdean 1435.

locations.name: Plora
locations.description: The Turnbulls killed a woman and her 2 sons here in 1494.

locations.name: Polmood
locations.description: A gang of Tweedys killed Edward Hunter here in 1502.

locations.name: Polwarth
locations.description: A man was murdered here on Packman Brae, date unknown.

locations.name: Prenderguest
locations.description: Alexander Home of Prenderguest murdered George Home of Spott in 1591, as part of a family feud.

locations.name: Prestonpans
locations.description: "Wanton Will” Jamesoun killed John Forbes with a stone in 1538 (and was then beheaded).

locations.name: Preston Tower
locations.description: Preston Tower was built by Sir Robert Harbottle (who had murdered a man in Methley, Yorkshire in 1392).

locations.name: Prickenhaugh Tower
locations.description: The notorious Gibb Elliot was killed here by a gang of men from Tynedale in 1597, after he had killed one of their men.

locations.name: Primside Farm
locations.description: Ralph Kerr of Primsideloch killed a man here in 1509.

locations.name: Redesdale
locations.description: the Rutherfords cut off Hugh Carlisle’s hand here in 1595. Locals killed 2 Scots here in 1598, as they were stealing timber and hunting illegally.

locations.name: Redeswire
locations.description: 25 Englishmen and 2 Scots were killed here after a supposed truce day in 1575. Scottish reivers killed a man here in 1587.

locations.name: Restalrig
locations.description: 25 men were killed in factional fighting here in 1559.  Another 100+ (mostly French) were killed here in 1560. Two men also attacked and killed John Borthwick in his home here in 1563. Both were beheaded in Edinburgh.

locations.name: Reston
locations.description: George Craw of Reston was involved in the killing of Lord Methven in 1572, by a cannon shot from Edinburgh Castle.

locations.name: Richmond
locations.description: The recorder of Berwick-upon-Tweed was almost assassinated here in 1597.

locations.name: Riskenhope
locations.description: The Tweedies killed many reivers here in 1587.

locations.name: River Tweed
locations.description: The Kerrs drowned a prisoner here in 1596 and hanged the other.

locations.name: Rookhope
locations.description: Locals killed several reivers here in 1572,  as they tried to raid the area.

locations.name: Rose Castle
locations.description: There was a plot to kill Lord Scrope here in 1598.

locations.name: Rothbury Forest
locations.description: Reivers from Redesdale killed 7 men here in 1518, as they ambushed the bailiff taking their comrades to Morpeth prison.

locations.name: Rowanburn
locations.description: Lang Sandie Armstrong of Rowanburn and his sons were hanged here in 1605, for the murder of Sir John Carmichael. A statue marks the spot.

locations.name: Roxburgh
locations.description: Richard Jack was beheaded for murder of Thomas Dun here in 1502.

locations.name: Roxburgh Castle
locations.description: King James II of Scotland was killed here in 1460, when one of his own cannons exploded. The Scots stormed the castle and killed everyone within it.

locations.name: Rule Water
locations.description: King James IV raided this place in 1510, taking reivers to be hanged at Jedburgh.

locations.name: Rutherford
locations.description: the Turnbulls killed John of Rutherford here in 1499. 3 Rutherford men killed Sir David Forbes in 1558.

locations.name: Saltoun
locations.description: Peter Downe was found guilty of a huge list of crimes (including slaughter, theft, burning and concealment) from 1554 to 1550 and was sentenced to death.

locations.name: Saltoun Castle
locations.description: Five Scottish traitors were hanged in 1548, after the siege of the castle.

locations.name: Sark
locations.description: Around 2,000 Scots and English were killed in battle here, in 1448.

locations.name: Scaleby
locations.description: Scottish reivers mutilated a man here in 1592 and killed one in 1600, leaving another in peril of his life. A Scot was attacked in revenge.

locations.name: Selkirk
locations.description: William Clerk killed 4 men here around 1494. Some Armstrongs murdered John Blackburn in 1501. The Kerrs murdered John Ford in 1502 and then the Provost and Bailie in 1541.

locations.name: Shieldgreen
locations.description: The Horsburghs attacked one of the Hays with pistols here in 1611.

locations.name: Shillmoor
locations.description: In 1597, locals complained that Sir John Foster beheaded a man here “for a small offence” while turning a blind eye to Scottish reivers.

locations.name: Shitlington
locations.description: William Charlton of Shitlington and 2 accomplices were killed near here by pursuers from a raid in 1528. They had kidnapped the parson of Muggleswick.

locations.name: Softlaw
locations.description: Will “Woddir-nek” Elliot, Peter “Monk” Trumbill and Henry Blake of Softlaw were all hanged for theft in the 1560s. 2 men were dismembered here in 1611.

locations.name: Solway Moss
locations.description: Hundreds of Scots were killed here in 1542, but mostly drowning while escaping through the river, rather than on the battlefield itself.

locations.name: South Charlton
locations.description: Reivers killed a man here in 1596.

locations.name: Sowerby
locations.description: The authorities killed a man here in 1297 for refusing to fight the Scots.

locations.name: Spedlins Castle
locations.description: Legend has it that a prisoner died here, after the owners went to Edinburgh and forgot about him.

locations.name: Spittal on Rule
locations.description: King James IV executed about 20 Turnbulls here (and a further 180 surrendered).

locations.name: Spott
locations.description: George Hume of Spot was accused of being one of the murderers of Lord Darnley in 1567. George Home of Spott was murdered in a field here, by his relative Alexander Home of Prenderguest in 1591. In 1597, Alexander was still a fugitive in England, along with 2 accomplices named Douglas.

locations.name: Spott Burn
locations.description: English forces defeated the Scots here in 1296, killing Sir Patrick Graham among many others.

locations.name: Sprouston
locations.description: Robert Paterson was hanged for burning corn here in 1554.

locations.name: Spylaw
locations.description: The English accused Sir John Kerr of Spylaw of “execrable murders” in 1597.

locations.name: Stanton
locations.description: William Clavering was shot dead (and his brother Sir Cuthbert Collingwood wounded) in an ambush by the Selbys here in 1586.

locations.name: Staplegordon Burn
locations.description: King James V executed John Armstrong of Staplegordon during his great raid against the reivers in 1530.

locations.name: St Mary's of the Lowes
locations.description: 200 Scotts broke down the kirk’s door, trying to kill Sir Peter Cranstoune in 1557.

locations.name: Stobo
locations.description: A gang of Tweedies cut a man's fingers off here and stabbed another man here in 1610. They also battered a man named Murray here in 1619 and left him for dead, but he recovered and escaped to Edinburgh to raise the alarm.

locations.name: Stonypath
locations.description: In 1561, Robert Douglas of Stonypath raided the house of Henry Carfra in Ridinghill, wounding him and killing his infant son. In 1568, Carfra and 6 friends got revenge by ambushing Douglas and leaving him for dead.

locations.name: Stow
locations.description: The Abbot of Melrose was excommunicated for attacking the Archbishop's Palace here in 1268 and killing a man. Jock Allane killed George Kay in 1569 and was subsequently beheaded.

locations.name: Swinton
locations.description: Many Scots were killed here in a 1558 skirmish.

locations.name: Synton
locations.description: Davy “the Lady” Scott killed 2 men here in 1502, on a raid with the Armstrongs. Andrew Crossar of Synton was drawn and hanged for committing 4 murders, stealing horses, burning and “bringing in Englishmen and traitors” in 1509.

locations.name: Tantallon Castle
locations.description: Douglas supporters killed 2 men here after the 1528 siege. Crown forces hanged 2 men in revenge in 1529.

locations.name: Tarset
locations.description: Scottish reivers killed 10 men here, in a raid at Michaelmas 1584.

locations.name: Tarset Burn
locations.description: The Armstrongs killed 6 people here in 1582.

locations.name: Teviotdale
locations.description: The Earl of Angus conducted a raid here in 1527, killing 18 reivers and hanging another 14 from a nearby bridge. The Elliots murdered a number of people here in 1564.

locations.name: Thirlestane Castle
locations.description: The Douglases seized Robert Cochrane, James Homyll and other favourites of King James III and hanged them from the bridge here in 1482. Walter Scott violently occupied this place 1502. In the mid-1500s, 3 members of the Lauder family were killed here in a feud.

locations.name: Thorneydykes
locations.description: The Frenche brothers shot and wounded two Home brothers near here in 1609. In 1613, Alexander Frenche was beheaded for the murder of John Crawford of Corsbie.

locations.name: Thornton
locations.description: Reivers killed 3 men and maimed 6 men and women in 1589.

locations.name: Thornton Castle
locations.description: English forces killed 10 men here in 1547.

locations.name: Threave Castle
locations.description: The Douglases murdered Patrick Maclellan here in 1452.

locations.name: Tinnis Castle
locations.description: The Pringles killed James Stewart of Tinnis in 1618, creating a feud.

locations.name: Tinwald
locations.description: Lord Maxwell murdered Sir James Johnstone here in 1608, at a supposed reconciliation.

locations.name: Troughend
locations.description: The Crosiers killed several of Reed’s men here in 1589. When he complained, they murdered him, with the help of the Halls.

locations.name: Tudhoe
locations.description: 500 Scots were slaughtered here, in 1346, before Nevilles Cross. As a result, the road became known as Butcher’s Race.

locations.name: Tushie Law
locations.description: Adam Scott of Tushie Law was listed for multiple thefts, slaughters and burnings in 1502. He and 5 others killed William Dalziel in 1512. The "King of thieves" was later found guilty of multiple offences including blackmail and was beheaded in Edinburgh in 1530. In 1612, Walter Scott of Tushielaw was murdered by the Tweedies.

locations.name: Twizel
locations.description: The Kerrs came looking for Storeys to kill here, in 1595.

locations.name: Tynedale
locations.description: Scottish reivers killed "dyvers" men here in 1525. English forces claimed to have killed as many as 120 reivers in 120. The Armstrongs killed 6 people and injured 11 in 1583. They killed another 10  men in 1584. In 1593, the Elliots killed 2 men in a feud here. Reivers killed another man in 1593, another 4 in 1595, 1 in 1596, 1 in 1597 and 2 more in 1598.

locations.name: Tynemouth
locations.description: Two jewel thieves (who had stolen from the Queen of Scotland) were caught here in 1594, before being sent to Edinburgh to be executed. A Scotsman was also stopped here in 1597, as he was on a mission to blow up Sir Robert Kerr.

locations.name: Ulgham
locations.description: Henry de Ellington was stabbed to death in a game of football in 1280.

locations.name: Wamphray
locations.description: Willie Johnstone of Wamphray (AKA The Galliard) was killed in the 1590s and the resulting feud with the Crichtons resulted in "considerable slaughter".

locations.name: Wampool
locations.description: The Grahams killed men in a raid here in 1600.

locations.name: Wark
locations.description: English forces from Wark garrison killed more than 50 Scots in 1524. As many as 300 French soldiers were killed here, in 1523, while besieging the castle (their Scottish allies having refused to cross the river). In 1595, the Kerrs came looking for Storeys to kill.

locations.name: Wauchope
locations.description: The Turnbulls of Wauchope admitted many crimes including slaughter and burning in 1502 and were denounced as rebels in 1529. John Lindsay of Wauchope was convicted of killing a messenger at arms and treason in 1505.

locations.name: Waughton Castle
locations.description: Sir Patrick Hepburn of Waughton was accused of many violent crimes in the 1530s. A later Sir Patrick killed a man near Coldingham in 1615, but escaped by shaking hands with the man’s master.

locations.name: Wedderburn Castle
locations.description: George Home of Wedderburn was killed raiding the English in 1497. His son David Home was found guilty of reiving (with 100 others) at Edinburgh that same year. In 1502 he was granted remission for the slaughter of John Lowdoune. In 1517, he was one of the main movers behind the murder of French diplomat Antoine de la Bastie. David himself was killed in an encounter with the English in 1524, then his son was killed at Pinkie. His son died in his bed in 1574 – said to be a first for the family.

locations.name: Weldon
locations.description: Nicholas Weldon of Weldon was listed as a notorious thief and murderer in 1597. Part of a criminal family (his uncle was executed for his crimes), he rode with the Fenwicks.

locations.name: Whitchester
locations.description: Robert Scott killed Adam Crawford here in 1494. The Scotts of Whitchester also feuded with other Scotts, with Scott of Allanhaugh and Whitchester assaulting Scott of Buccleuch's wife with a long staff in 1541.

locations.name: Whitmuir Hall
locations.description: Two Whitmuir men killed a man here in 1502. And in 1509, William Kerr of Whitmuir murdered a man called John Broune.

locations.name: Whitslaid
locations.description: The Lauders of Whitslaid killed George Wedderat in 1565, as part of an old feud.

locations.name: Widdrington
locations.description: The Lisles came to murder Sir William Ellerker in 1527.

locations.name: Wideopen
locations.description: A Dagliesh was “cut all in pieces” by Carey’s men in 1596 in revenge for stealing 2 of his horses. The barbarity of this reached Queen Elizabeth herself, who said the act was “verie barabarous and seldom used among the Turckes”. Carey got into a series of letters where he vehemently denied that the body was cut in as many pieces as reported.

locations.name: Wigtown
locations.description: Thomas McLellan and 4 other men were declared outlaws for murdering George Frere in 1509. In 1509, the Sheriff of Wigtown Patrick Agnew was convicted of taking bribes to acquit murderers. In 1512 and 1513, he was found guilty of many other violent offences including the murder of Patrick McKee. Another man – Patrick Mclellan - was beheaded for stealing 20 oxen from Agnew in 1510. Thomas Mure was found guilty of many violent offences here in 1512. Thomas Porter was beheaded here in 1513 for the cruel slaughter of John Makmyane. Many violent offences (mutilations, thefts and oppressions) were reported in Wigtown that year. The Provost of Wigtown was murdered in 1610.

locations.name: Willimoteswick Castle
locations.description: Scottish reivers killed William Ridley of Willimoteswick and 2 others in 1598.

locations.name: Windy Gyle
locations.description: The Kerrs killed Lord Francis Russell here in 1585, at a supposed Truce Day.

locations.name: Wingates
locations.description: The Elliots once killed a man here and maimed others.

locations.name: Woodside
locations.description: The Scotts killed a man here in 1587.

locations.name: Wooler
locations.description: The Kerrs killed 3 Storeys here, in 1595. The locals rode into Scotland and killed a shepherd of the Kerrs as a revenge, prolonging the feud.

locations.name: Yarrow Kirk
locations.description: John Scott killed his brother-in-law Robert Scott in a duel here (year unknown but early 1500s).

locations.name: Yeavering
locations.description: English forces killed 60 Scots here in 1415

locations.name: York
locations.description: The Earl of Nottingham killed the Earl of Dunbar in a duel here, in 1390. He had been issued a safe-conduct to visit England, specifically for this purpose. The Taits tracked down one of the killers of Robert Kerr and decapitated him in 1508. They brought the head back to Scotland in a bag.

locations.name: Abbey Saint Bathans
locations.description: English forces burnt the priory here, in 1543. They also burnt the village in 1544.

locations.name: Acomb
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1467, to the outrage of the Archbishop of York, who owned it.

locations.name: Aikwood Tower
locations.description: Reivers stole 100 cattle from here in 1502.

locations.name: Akeld
locations.description: Scots forces burnt this place in 1297. A gang of Kerrs also tried to ambush the Storeys between here and Humbleton in 1595.

locations.name: Allanbank
locations.description: English forces burnt this place (then known as East Nisbet) in 1523 and 1545.

locations.name: Allanton
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1482.

locations.name: Allendale
locations.description: The Blenkinsopps of Bellister raided this place in 1605.

locations.name: Allerdale District
locations.description: Scottish forces ravaged this place in 1297 and 1318.

locations.name: Allergarth
locations.description: The Elliots stole 70 beasts and burnt houses here in 1596.

locations.name: Allerwash
locations.description: Scottish reivers stole 19 beasts here in 1589.

locations.name: Alnham
locations.description: Scottish reivers raided this place in 1532 and 1587.

locations.name: Alnmouth
locations.description: Humphrey Lisle gang robbed the house of Thomas Dryden in 1527.

locations.name: Alwinton
locations.description: Reivers stole 12 cattle from here in 1588.

locations.name: Amisfield
locations.description: English forces burnt this place (including the crops) in 1547, with 4,000 beasts taken.

locations.name: Ancrum
locations.description: A mixed gang of Dalglieshes, Turnbulls and English reivers burnt this place in 1510. English forces burnt the place in 1543 and 1545.

locations.name: Annan
locations.description: English forces destroyed this town in 1513 (along with 33 other hamlets),1516, 1523, 1547 and 1596. The Maxwells fought the Johnstones here in 1585 and 1586. In 1592 English reivers stole 40 horses – and another 30 cattle in 1597.

locations.name: Annandale
locations.description: English forces ravaged this area in 1297.

locations.name: Appleby
locations.description: Scottish forces destroyed this place in 1174 (capturing the castle in a dawn raid), 1314, 1318, 1388 (the castle held out against 4 Scottish attacks in this period), 1457 and 1458.

locations.name: Applegarth
locations.description: The Jardines fought off an English invasion here, with French help, in 1547. The Jardines were also attacked by the Grahams here in 1571, with 80 cattle stolen, corn burnt, 2 men killed and 1 kidnapped.

locations.name: Ardwell
locations.description: Reivers burnt this place in 1508.

locations.name: Askerton
locations.description: The Scotts stole 300 cattle from here in 1595, with the collusion of Thomas Carleton.

locations.name: Aspatria
locations.description: Reivers stole 4 horses from here in 1592.

locations.name: Athelstaneford
locations.description: Local man George Hepburn was found guilty of assisting the English in 1548.

locations.name: Attonburn
locations.description: English forces destroyed this place in1545. The locals repelled 80 Berwick reivers from here in 1596.

locations.name: Auchen Castle
locations.description: Scottish forces destroyed the castle in the 1300s, to prevent it falling into English hands. It was rebuilt and burnt by the English in 1547.

locations.name: Auchenrivock
locations.description: English forces burnt the tower here, in 1513.

locations.name: Aydon
locations.description: Scottish forces ravaged this place in 1311, 1312, 1315, 1346 and 1448.

locations.name: Aydon Castle
locations.description: Scottish forces attacked this castle in 1312, 1315, 1346 and 1448. English looters also damaged it in 1317.

locations.name: Ayton
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1448, 1497, 1533 and 1542

locations.name: Ayton Tower
locations.description: This tower was held by the English 1547-1550.

locations.name: Bamburgh
locations.description: Scottish forces attacked the town and castle many times, including 1138, 1319, 1328, 1333, 1401 and 1480. In 1596, Sir John Foster complained that Scottish reivers had stolen goods worth £1,000 in the last year.

locations.name: Barefoots
locations.description: Scottish troops fought off an English force here in 1557. The Scots had only just risen, so had to fight in bare feet, giving the place its name.

locations.name: Barnhills
locations.description: In 1502, the Turnbulls of Barnhills admitted various burnings and murders.

locations.name: Barnhills Tower
locations.description: English forces burnt this tower in 1545.

locations.name: Barmoor Woods
locations.description: Reivers once took 18 oxen and 3 horses here.

locations.name: Barnard Castle
locations.description: Scottish forces attacked this place in 1216 and 1318.

locations.name: Bassendean
locations.description: The Halls stole a horse here in 1510. Robert Hall was sentenced to be hanged.

locations.name: Bavington
locations.description: Scottish reivers stole over 60 sheep here in 1587 and 20 beasts in 1589.

locations.name: Beanley
locations.description: Scottish reivers stole 100 sheep here, in 1587.

locations.name: Bearpark
locations.description: Scottish forces sacked this place 1326-7.

locations.name: Bedrule
locations.description: The Olivers stole sheep here in1502. English forces burnt it in 1545. Some men were indicted for theft of 24 sheep here in 1596.

locations.name: Bellingham
locations.description: Scottish reivers raided this place in 1597, leaving 200 men “spoiled and nearly beggared.”

locations.name: Bellister
locations.description: Scottish reivers burnt 25 houses and took goods worth more than £1000 from here.

locations.name: Belton
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1544.

locations.name: Bemersyde
locations.description: English forces destroyed the castle here in 1545. English reivers stole 8 oxen in 1596.

locations.name: Berwick Bounds
locations.description: The Pringles stole 30 sheep, 6 geldings and 1 mare here, in 2 separate raids in 1596.

locations.name: Berwick-upon-Tweed
locations.description: This town changed hands between Scotland and England 13 times, with some of the most notable sieges in 1296, 1318, 1333 and 1482. It was also constantly attacked by Scottish reivers. For instance, in 1524, they attacked men going to market. In 1588, they stole 27 beasts. In 1589, they stole 10 beasts. In 1603, the Humes and Carrs raided the town.

locations.name: Bewcastle
locations.description: This town was raided constantly: in fact, Scottish reivers attacked it 11 times in the summer of 1581 alone. Notable raids include one by the Armstrongs in 1583, where a man was killed; one by the Elliots in 1584, where 80 beasts were stolen; one by the Scotts in 1587, where 500 beasts were taken; another one in 1588 where the Scotts took 70 beasts and killed 4 people; one in 1592, where the Armstrongs stole 60 cattle, 40 sheep, horse and killed a man; one in 1594 where 80 cattle were taken and many men left for dead; one in 1599, when the Armstrongs took 160 beasts and killed a man. In 1602, reivers burnt houses here in a revenge attack.

locations.name: Biggar
locations.description: The Liddesdale reivers raided this place in 1567.

locations.name: Billie Castle
locations.description: English forces burnt this tower in 1544 and 1548. English reivers raided it in 1596.

locations.name: Birdoswald
locations.description: Scottish reivers took 50 cattle from here in 1588. They also stole 40 cows and 40 sheep here in 1596, while burning and cutting up the doors.

locations.name: Birgham
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1545.

locations.name: Birkshaw
locations.description: Reivers raided this place in 1529.

locations.name: Bite-about Wood
locations.description: English forces destroyed the tower here, in 1544/5.

locations.name: Blackadder
locations.description: English forces burnt the castle here in 1482, 1522 and 1523.

locations.name: Blackburn
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1544.

locations.name: Blackhall Wood
locations.description: Scottish forces destroyed this place in 1380.

locations.name: Black Law
locations.description: 400 Armstrongs stole 80 cattle, 1000 sheep one Midsummer in the 1570s.

locations.name: Black Middens Bastle House
locations.description: The Armstrongs attacked this fortified house in 1583.

locations.name: Blackness
locations.description: The English navy burnt Scottish ships here in 1481.

locations.name: Blanchland Abbey
locations.description: Scottish forces attacked this place in 1346.

locations.name: Blanerne
locations.description: English forces destroyed the castle here in 1544.

locations.name: Blawearie Wood
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1523.

locations.name: Blencarn
locations.description: Reivers stole 40 sheep from here in 1592.

locations.name: Blencow
locations.description: Reivers stole 6 sheep from here in 1592.

locations.name: Bloodylaws
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1523.

locations.name: Blyth Bridge
locations.description: The Flemings attacked this place in 1545.

locations.name: Bolton Fell
locations.description: Bolton Fell – reivers stole 30 cattle, 10 sheep and a horse here in 1592. Diverse people were also wounded.

locations.name: Bongate
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1545.

locations.name: Bonjedward
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1543 and 1545.

locations.name: Bonkyll Castle
locations.description: English forces destroyed this place in 1544.

locations.name: Bonshaw Tower
locations.description: English forces burnt the tower in 1544 and blew it up with gunpowder before 1570. The Johnstones raided it in the 1580s and the Maxwells in 1585.

locations.name: Boreland
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1544.

locations.name: Borthwickshiels
locations.description: 3 Armstrong brothers burnt this place and stole cattle in 1502.

locations.name: Botcherby
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1380.

locations.name: Bothal Castle
locations.description: Scottish reivers burnt the tower here in 1388 and 1498.

locations.name: Bow
locations.description: The Grahams burnt this place in 1603.

locations.name: Bowhill
locations.description: The Turnbulls stole cattle from here in 1494.

locations.name: Bowland
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1544.

locations.name: Bowsden
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1297.

locations.name: Brampton
locations.description: Scottish forces destroyed this place in 1297 and 1375. Reivers raided 5 houses here in 1592. A gang of Grahams tried to burn John Musgrave alive here in 1600. There were further raids in 1602.

locations.name: Brancepeth
locations.description: Scottish forces sacked this place in 1388.

locations.name: Branton
locations.description: Scottish reivers took 30 cattle, 6 horses, silver and gold from here in 1587.

locations.name: Branxholm
locations.description: This place was burnt by a mixed gang of Dalglieshes, Turnbulls and English reivers in 1510. And by English forces in 1532 and 1570.

locations.name: Branxton
locations.description: Scottish forces attacked this place in 1524 and 1545. And in 1596, they stole 80 sheep and 16 cattle here.

locations.name: Brigend
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1545.

locations.name: Brinkburn Priory
locations.description: Scottish forces sacked the priory in 1315 and 1322. Then in 1419 ‘evildoers’ raided the priory and took all its valuables. Beasts were also stolen by reivers in 1441 and 1484.

locations.name: Broadmeadows
locations.description: The Cranstons attacked Alexander Hoppringill near here and killed some of his cattle in 1566. The Hoppringills took immediate revenge by attacking Cranston and his cattle. Later that year, Hoppringill was also charged with mutilating John Scott’s arm.

locations.name: Bromfield
locations.description: Reivers stole 15 sheep here in 1592.

locations.name: Broomhill Farm
locations.description: English forces destroyed this place in 1482.

locations.name: Brough
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this town in 1174, 1314, 1319 and 1388.

locations.name: Brougham Castle
locations.description: Scottish forces captured this castle in 1388.

locations.name: Broughton
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1544.

locations.name: Brox Law
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1545.

locations.name: Brunston Castle
locations.description: English forces destroyed this in 1547.

locations.name: Buccleuch
locations.description: Although this was a Scott stronghold, another branch of the Scotts (of Allanhaugh and Whitchester) conducted violent raids on it in 1541.

locations.name: Buckholm
locations.description: 300 Armstrongs and Elliots sacked the tower here and murdered its owner George Hoppringle, in 1568.

locations.name: Budle
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1297.

locations.name: Buittle
locations.description: The Bruces captured the castle here in 1286 and 1308. The Balliols recaptured it in 1332, before the Douglases seized it in 1456.

locations.name: Burgh-by-Sands
locations.description: Scottish forces destroyed this place in 1297 and 1375. The Maxwells stole 25 horses here in 1593.

locations.name: Butterdean
locations.description: English forces destroyed this place in 1544.

locations.name: Bywell
locations.description: Scottish forces destroyed this place in 1297.

locations.name: Caerlaverock Castle
locations.description: This castle was besieged several times by both Scotland and England, from 1300 to 1570. In one celebrated raid in 1547, the Curwens stole the castle gates and sailed back to Workington with them.

locations.name: Caldbeck
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1297. Reivers also assaulted a man in his own home here in 1593, burning his buttocks and belly with a hot iron.

locations.name: Calder Abbey
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this church in 1314, 1315 and 1322.

locations.name: Caldra
locations.description: English forces destroyed this place in 1545.

locations.name: Calvertsholm
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1513.

locations.name: Canonbie
locations.description: English forces destroyed this area in 1513 and 1527.

locations.name: Cardoness
locations.description: Ninian McCulloch broke into a barn and stole 1,500 beasts from his own mother, in 1501.

locations.name: Cargo
locations.description: The Grahams operated a protection racket here. In 1603, a band of 140 Grahams ate and drank for free here, while on the run.

locations.name: Carham
