locations.description: Scottish forces destroyed this place in 1296 and 1542.

locations.name: Carlatton
locations.description: Scottish forces destroyed this place in 1315.

locations.name: Carlisle
locations.description: Scottish forces attacked the town many times including 1136, 1173, 1174, 1215, 1216, 1295, 1297, 1301, 1314, 1315 and 4 times 1380-1390. In 1596, Scottish reivers staged a notorious prison break out, to free Kinmont Willie Armstrong and there were many other prison escapes in this time. In 1602, 200 Scottish reivers raided the town.

locations.name: Carterhope Burn
locations.description: Richard Pott of Eskdale stole almost 100 sheep here in 1513 and was hanged as a result.

locations.name: Cartington
locations.description: Reivers took 30 sheep here in 1589.

locations.name: Carwinley
locations.description: Reivers stole 240 cattle, 20 horses and 100 sterling in 1596.

locations.name: Castle Carrock
locations.description: Castle Carrock reivers stole 20 cattle from Geisdale in 1596.

locations.name: Castlemilk
locations.description: English forces destroyed this place in 1547.

locations.name: Castle Sowerby
locations.description: Castle Sowerby– Scottish forces burnt this place in 1314 and 1315. It was also savagely raided in 1592.

locations.name: Catslack
locations.description: English forces burnt this tower in 1548

locations.name: Cavers
locations.description: James Douglas of Cavers stole 300 cattle from Henry Wodrington in 1596. English reivers stole 78 sheep from Cavers that same year.

locations.name: Cavers Castle
locations.description: English forces seized this castle in 1311, then burnt it in 1523, 1532, 1535, 1541, 1542, 1545 and 1596.

locations.name: Caverton
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1545.

locations.name: Cessford Burn
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1545.

locations.name: Cessford Castle
locations.description: English forces attacked this castle in 1519, 1522, 1523, 1543 and 1544. The Elliots stole 80 sheep from here in 1576.

locations.name: Charterhouse Farm
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1542 and 1545. English reivers also stole 10 cattle here in 1596.

locations.name: Charlton
locations.description: Reivers took 30 cattle from here in 1588.

locations.name: Chatto
locations.description: Reivers from the Dalgliesh family broke into the house of some Rutherfords here in 1510.

locations.name: Chatton
locations.description: This place was described as badly affected by Scottish raids in 1564. Reivers also took 4 cattle from here in 1589.

locations.name: Cherrytreees
locations.description: English forces destroyed this place in 1482 and 1545.

locations.name: Cheswick
locations.description: Thomas Armstrong of Cheswick stole a horse from Scotland in 1596.

locations.name: Chillingham Castle
locations.description: Scottish forces besieged the castle in 1296. English forces besieged it in 1536 during the Pilgrimage of Grace.

locations.name: Chipchase Castle
locations.description: Over 1588 and 1589, the Armstrongs stole 15 horses here. The Elliots also stole a horse here in 1589.

locations.name: Chirnside
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1497 and 1565 “with some slaughter”

locations.name: Chirnside Mains
locations.description: James Home of Chirnside Mains was part of a band of 1,000 Humes who raided the Kerrs of Ferniehurst in 1565.

locations.name: Choicelee
locations.description: The Cockburns of Choicelee helped an English reiver to escape in 1538 - and paid some Kerrs to terrorise and wound the minister of Langton in 1588.

locations.name: Chollerford
locations.description: The Lisles robbed 2 men of their horses and weapons in 1527.

locations.name: Chollerton
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1388-89.

locations.name: Chorley
locations.description: Scottish forces raided here in 1322.

locations.name: Cleithaugh
locations.description: Thomas Aynsley of Cleithaugh stole 16 oxen, 9 horses and a dog from Haggerston in 1596.

locations.name: Clennell
locations.description: Scottish reivers stole 60 beasts here in 1587. In 1596, the Laird of Clennell stole 4 sheep from Scotland.

locations.name: Cliftoncote
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1482.

locations.name: Closeburn
locations.description: The Johnstones raided this place in 1585, during a spree which took 18 lives.

locations.name: Coates
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1549.

locations.name: Cockburnspath
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1532, with the help of rebels like Alexander Hume (who was later beheaded). “Feeble” Hob Turnbull raided it in 1537, stealing 20 cattle and wounding several people with lances.

locations.name: Cockermouth
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1297 and 1385.

locations.name: Cocklaw Tower
locations.description: English forces attacked the castle in 1401.

locations.name: Coldingham
locations.description: English forces (helped by the Earl of Angus) burnt the town in 1532. The Humes robbed and wounded people here in 1538. English forces burnt it again in 1545.

locations.name: Coldingham Priory
locations.description: English forces besieged the priory in 1216, 1430, 1532, 1544 and 1545.

locations.name: Coldstream
locations.description: English forces attacked this place many times including 1296, 1543 and 1545. Scottish forces also attacked it in 1310.

locations.name: Coldstream Priory
locations.description: English forces attacked the priory in 1296 and Scottish soldiers in 1310. Soldiers from Wark stole a load of oats from the priory in 1523 and English soldiers dispersed the nuns in 1543 and 1545.

locations.name: Comlongon Castle
locations.description: English forces captured the tower in 1547.

locations.name: Corbet Tower
locations.description: English forces destroyed this tower in 1522, 1544 and 1545. Reivers also raided it, including in 1502.

locations.name: Corbridge
locations.description: Scottish forces attacked this place many times including 1138, 1296, 1297, 1311, 1312 , 1346 and 1399.

locations.name: Corby
locations.description: The Grahams robbed this place in 1600.

locations.name: Cornhill-on-Tweed
locations.description: Scottish forces attacked this place many times including 1385, 1496, 1524, 1542, 1544 and 1545.

locations.name: Corsbie
locations.description: The Humes of Corsbie stole 5 bolls of malt from Learmouth in 1596.

locations.name: Coupland
locations.description: Scottish troops burnt this place in 1315 and 1318. Scottish reivers raided it in 1579 and 1596 (when they cut doors down with axes and stole over 40 beasts).

locations.name: Cousland
locations.description: Reivers raided this place in 1528. English forces destroyed it in 1549.

locations.name: Covington
locations.description: The Douglases burnt this place in 1494.

locations.name: Cowbog
locations.description: English forces destroyed this place in 1544.

locations.name: Cowdenknowes
locations.description: English forces attacked this place in 1544 and 1546.

locations.name: Crackenthorpe
locations.description: Scottish reivers raided this place in 1595, stealing almost 100 beasts.

locations.name: Craigmillar Castle
locations.description: English forces burnt this castle in 1544.

locations.name: Crailing
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1482 and 1545.

locations.name: Cramlington
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1385 and 1388-89.

locations.name: Cranshaws
locations.description: Lord Oliphant raided this town, stealing oxen and horses, in 1476.

locations.name: Craster
locations.description: Scottish reivers took 5 cattle from here in 1587.

locations.name: Crawford
locations.description: The Bells and Armstrongs raided here in 1585.

locations.name: Crookedshaws
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1545.

locations.name: Crosby-on-Eden
locations.description: Scottish forces attacked this place in 1297.

locations.name: Cruggleton Castle
locations.description: The castle was captured several times by both English and Scottish forces.

locations.name: Cumcrook
locations.description: Scottish reivers stole 46 beasts from here in 1592.

locations.name: Cumwhitton
locations.description: The Grahams robbed this place in 1600.

locations.name: Dalcove Tower
locations.description: English forces burnt this tower in 1545.

locations.name: Dalhousie Castle
locations.description: English forces burnt this tower in 1400. Henry IV attended the siege in person - the last time an English king did this in Scotland.

locations.name: Dalkeith
locations.description: English forces burnt this place (and everything in a 6 mile radius) in 1548.

locations.name: Dalveen
locations.description: The Johnstones stole 30 cattle from the Douglases here in 1597.

locations.name: Darlington
locations.description: Scottish forces attacked this place in 1322 and 1327.

locations.name: Darnchester
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1545.

locations.name: Darnick
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1545. The Olivers raided it in 1502.

locations.name: Davyshiel
locations.description: Scottish reivers seriously injured 2 men, while stealing 20 beasts in 1588. In 1589, they stole 6 oxen.

locations.name: Deanbrae Law
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1544.

locations.name: Debatable Land
locations.description: This was the scene (and source) of constant raids. In 1536, the Scots and English mounted a joint raid to try and burn the culprits out. In 1537 and 1551, both Governments declared that anybody could rob, kill and burn here without punishment.

locations.name: Denholm
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1532, with the help of the Scotts. They also burnt it in 1545.

locations.name: Denwick
locations.description: Scottish reivers stole all the village’s horses in 1596. The locals recovered them and killed the reiver leader – an infamous fellow named James Burne – with a shot in the back.

locations.name: Devil's Beef Tub
locations.description: The Johnstones used to hide their stolen cattle in this gully, until their pursuers had given up.

locations.name: Ditchburn
locations.description: Scottish reivers took 40 beasts from here in 1587.

locations.name: Doddington
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1297.

locations.name: Dolphinston
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1523.

locations.name: Donkleywood
locations.description: The Scotts conducted a huge raid here in 1597, killing 35 people in the process (including 7 burnt alive).

locations.name: Dormanstead
locations.description: The Grahams stole 24 cattle from here in 1596.

locations.name: Dornock
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1378, 1513 and 1523.

locations.name: Downham
locations.description: The Kerrs raided this place in 1596, breaking doors down with axes.

locations.name: Drumburgh
locations.description: The Armstrongs raided this place in 1602.

locations.name: Drumelzier
locations.description: The Scotts stole 4000 sheep, 200 cattle and 40 horses from the Tweedies in 1592. The Flemings burnt this place in 1545.

locations.name: Drumlanrig
locations.description: English forces raided this place in 1548, only to be ambushed.

locations.name: Drumlanrig's Tower
locations.description: Reivers raided this place in 1548, 1585 and 1597.

locations.name: Dryburgh Abbey
locations.description: English forces destroyed this place 4 times: in 1322, 1385, 1544 and 1545.

locations.name: Dryfesdale
locations.description: The Maxwells burnt this place in 1585.

locations.name: Dryhope Tower
locations.description: This tower was slighted after 1592, to punish the Scotts for supporting a plot against the king.

locations.name: Duddo Tower
locations.description: Scottish forces destroyed this tower in 1496 and raided it again in 1545.

locations.name: Dumfries
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1380, 1384, 1415, 1448 (along with 44 other towns), 1482, 1536, 1542 (twice), 1544 and 1596. The Johnstones burnt it in 1586.

locations.name: Dunbar
locations.description: English forces attacked the town in 1216, 1226, 1337, 1338, 1417, 1448, 1544 and 1548. German mercenaries attacked it in 1549.

locations.name: Dunbar Castle
locations.description: English forces attacked the castle in 1216, 1226, 1337, 1338 and 1417. It was later slighted by the Scots, rebuilt, attacked by Humes, attacked by English in 1548, then finally slighted by the Scots in 1567.

locations.name: Duncow
locations.description: The Johnstones burnt this place in 1585, during their feud with the Maxwells.

locations.name: Duncanhaugh
locations.description: Reivers stole 17 cattle from the Pringles here, in 1596.

locations.name: Dundrennan Abbey

locations.name: Duns

locations.name: Dunskey

locations.name: Dunskey Castle
locations.description: English forces burnt the castle in 1489.

locations.name: Dunstan
locations.description: The Youngs stole 7 cattle and 2 horses here in 1596. Scottish reivers also broke down doors and stole 40 cattle here, in 1597.

locations.name: Durham
locations.description: Scottish forces attacked this place in 1006, 1040, 1091, 1312, 1315, 1322 and 1342. The Herons burnt and robbed a house in the Bishops bank in 1603 (they were later caught and hanged).

locations.name: Durisdeer
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1547.

locations.name: Earnslaw
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1482.

locations.name: East Barns

locations.name: East Ditchburn

locations.name: Eccles
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1523, 1542, 1543 and 1545.

locations.name: Eckford
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1523, 1544, 1545 and 1570.

locations.name: Edenhall
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1385 and 1388. Reivers stole 30 sheep here in 1592.

locations.name: Edgerston
locations.description: The castle here was besieged by Crown forces in 1536.

locations.name: Edinburgh
locations.description: English forces attacked the city many times - most notably 1296, 1385 and 1544.

locations.name: Edinburgh - Barnton
locations.description: The Douglases burnt Barnton Castle in 1443, during a power struggle with the Crichtons.

locations.name: Edinburgh - Bruntsfield House
locations.description: English forces burnt this house in 1544.

locations.name: Edinburgh Castle
locations.description: This castle was besieged 23 times, making it the most besieged place in the UK, if not Europe.

locations.name: Edinburgh - Drylaw
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1544.

locations.name: Edinburgh - Duddingston
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1544.

locations.name: Edinburgh - Figgate
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1544.

locations.name: Edinburgh - Gilmerton
locations.description: English places burnt this place and destroyed its tower in 1547.

locations.name: Edinburgh - Granton
locations.description: English forces landed near here in 1544, burning the castle and surrounding area.

locations.name: Edinburgh - Holyrood
locations.description: English forces destroyed the abbey in 1322.

locations.name: Edinburgh - Inverleith
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1544.

locations.name: Edinburgh - Lauriston Castle
locations.description: English forces destroyed the castle in 1544.

locations.name: Edinburgh - Lochend Castle
locations.description: The Provost of Edinburgh attacked this castle in 1586, in a dispute over land access.

locations.name: Edinburgh - Wardie Castle
locations.description: English forces burnt this castle in 1544.

locations.name: Edington
locations.description: 800 English reivers attacked this place in 1565.

locations.name: Ednam
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1482, 1496, 1523, 1542, 1544, 1545 and 1558. A gang of 200 men mobbed a messenger here in 1510. The Humes raided it in 1535 “in warlike manner with lances, bows and arrows.” One servant was left in peril of life.

locations.name: Edrington
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1482, 1546 and 1558.

locations.name: Edrington Castle
locations.description: The castle here was captured by the English several times including 1533. In 1542, King James V sent an order to the Captain of Dunbar castle to blow it up “with two half-barrels of powder” as it had been taken and strengthened by the English. But the order was never carried out.  It was valiantly defended by 16 Frenchmen in 1558.

locations.name: Edrom
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1482 and 1544.

locations.name: Eglingham
locations.description: The Youngs stole 6 cattle from here in 1587. The Kerrs stole 100 sheep from here in 1596.

locations.name: Eglingham
locations.description: A gang of Scots raided the village in 1602, only to be repelled by locals, who took 20 horses.

locations.name: Egremont
locations.description: Scottish forces destroyed this place in 1315 and 1322.

locations.name: Eildon
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1545.

locations.name: Elishaw
locations.description: Scottish reivers stole many cattle from here in 1582.

locations.name: Ellingham
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1297. Reivers stole 30 cattle from here in 1596.

locations.name: Embleton
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1297 and 1383.

locations.name: Eshott
locations.description: The Lisle gang burnt Roger Heron’s house here in 1527.

locations.name: Eslington
locations.description: Scottish reivers raided this place in 1587, 1589 and 1595.

locations.name: Etal
locations.description: Scottish forces captured the castle in 1513. The Humes raided this place in 1596.

locations.name: Etterby
locations.description: Scottish reivers stole over 60 beasts and wounded 6 people in 1592.

locations.name: Ettrick Forest
locations.description: Sim 'the Laird' Armstrong stole sheep here in 1535 and was later hanged for a long list of offences.

locations.name: Eyemouth
locations.description: English naval forces landed and attacked the town in 1542. They also tried to burn the mill in 1588 but found that the turf roof made it difficult.

locations.name: Fala
locations.description: English forces (from Wark Castle) burnt this place in 1544.

locations.name: Fa'side Castle
locations.description: English forces burnt this place before the Battle of Pinkie in 1547.

locations.name: Fast Castle
locations.description: English forces captured this castle in 1346, 1547 and 1570. Scottish forces destroyed it in 1515, to punish the treacherous Lord Home.

locations.name: Fastheugh
locations.description: Turnbulls burnt this place and stole cattle in 1494 and 1502.

locations.name: Fatlips Castle
locations.description: English forces burnt this castle in 1545.

locations.name: Fauldshope
locations.description: James Gray of Fauldshope stole 400 sheep in 1502.

locations.name: Fawdon
locations.description: 100 Redesdale men raided the manor house here in 1267 and almost decapitated William de Douglas. Scottish reivers stole 40 beasts from here in 1587.

locations.name: Featherstone
locations.description: Reivers burnt 23 houses and barns here in 1587. In 1596, reivers stole 50 cows and seriously injured several men.

locations.name: Felkington
locations.description: 700 Kerrs raided this place in 1533. Reivers stole 5 beasts here in 1596.

locations.name: Felton
locations.description: King John’s army burnt this town in 1215 after the people had switched to pay homage to the Scottish king. Scottish forces burnt it in 1297. The Eures burnt numerous houses while searching for the Lisle gang, who had escaped from Newcastle gaol in 1527.

locations.name: Fenton
locations.description: Scottish forces wasted this place in 1558. Reivers stole 12 cattle from here in 1596, leaving one man badly hurt.

locations.name: Ferniehurst Castle
locations.description: English forces attacked this place in 1523, 1549, 1570 and 1573. 1,000 Humes raided the Kerrs here in 1565.

locations.name: Fethan
locations.description: The Scotts raided a tower and shot people in 1603.

locations.name: Fishwick
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1482 and 1542.

locations.name: Flodden
locations.description: The Border reivers (of both sides) disgraced themselves after the battle in 1513, by looting the dead.

locations.name: Floors
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1542.

locations.name: Fogo
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1545. English reivers stole 8 cattle from here in 1596.

locations.name: Ford
locations.description: Scottish reivers stole 140 sheep from here in 1596. That same year, men from Ford stole 10 cattle from the Scots.

locations.name: Ford Castle
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this castle many times including 1385, 1513, 1524, 1540 and 1549.

locations.name: Foulden
locations.description: English forces burnt this place (including the tower) in 1523.

locations.name: Foulsyke
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1513.

locations.description: Scottish forces attacked this place in 1318.

locations.name: Fulton Tower
locations.description: English forces burnt this tower in 1523 and 1545.

locations.name: Furness
locations.description: Scottish forces attacked this place in 1316.

locations.name: Gamelshiels
locations.description: John Forester of Gamelshiels and 60 others went raiding in Berwick in 1561.

locations.name: Gateshaw
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1522 and 1545. English reivers stole 200 sheep in 1596. The people of Gateshaw stole 100 sheep from England that year too.

locations.name: Geltsdale
locations.description: Walter Scott of Harden and a gang of Elliots stole 3 horses here in 1595.

locations.name: Gilcrux
locations.description: Scottish reivers stole a horse here in 1592.

locations.name: Gilnockie Tower
locations.description: English forces burnt this tower in 1528. The Musgraves stole 400 cattle, 200 sheep, 20 horse and gold from the Armstrongs here in 1597.

locations.name: Gilsland
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1297 and 1389. The town was also constantly raided by Scottish reivers. For instance they burnt 30 steadings in 1561. They also came in 1581, seriously wounding one person and stealing 15 beasts. In 1589, they took 70 cattle in a series of raids. In 1592 they took 200 beasts and seriously wounded some locals. In 1595, they stole over 300 cattle and horses. In 1596, they stole 300 cattle and 20 horses while burning 20 houses and mutilating many men. In 1597, they stole almost 300 beasts. The reivers responsible for these raids included the colourfully-named George “Buggerback” Elliott, Archie “Dog pyntle” Elliott and Hob “Bane Prick” Elliott.

locations.name: Girsonfield Burn
locations.description: Scottish reivers stole 30 beasts from here in 1587.

locations.name: Girthon
locations.description: A man was besieged by his enemies “in a warlike manner” at the church here in 1504.

locations.name: Glanton
locations.description: Scottish reivers took 60 beasts from here in raids 1587-1588. They burnt the place in 1596.

locations.name: Glassonby
locations.description: Scottish reivers stole over 200 beasts from here in 1592.

locations.name: Gleaston
locations.description: Scottish forces raided this place in 1316.

locations.name: Glengelt
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1544.

locations.name: Gordon
locations.description: English reivers raided this place in 1563.

locations.name: Grahamslaw
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1523, 1542 and 1545.

locations.name: Great Ryle Tower
locations.description: Mercenaries captured this tower in 1549. Armstrongs attacked it in 1587.

locations.name: Great Salkeld
locations.description: Reivers stole 30 sheep from here in 1592.

locations.name: Greenhaugh
locations.description: The Scotts burnt a widow’s house here in 1595, while looking for some Charltons to kill.

locations.name: Greenhead
locations.description: Reivers stole cattle here in 1596 and 3 horses in 1601.

locations.name: Greenlaw
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1544.

locations.name: Gretna
locations.description: Willie Johnstone stole a horse here in 1592: a simple crime which sparked a chain of feuding which cost hundreds of lives. The Irvines were also burnt out of here around 1597.

locations.name: Grindon
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1545. The Kerrs stole 40 sheep here in 1596. Scottish reivers stole 100 sheep in 1597.

locations.name: Grubbit
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1545

locations.name: Halton
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1388-89. The Armstrongs burnt William Carnaby’s corn here in 1541.

locations.name: Hadden
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1542.

locations.name: Haddington
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1216, 1244, 1356, 1384, 1523, 1544 and 1548. They captured the town and held it from 1548 to 1549, until the Scots ejected them. Scottish forces also burnt the town in 1298.

locations.name: Haddington Priory
locations.description: Reivers stole 2 horses from the prioress here in 1502.

locations.name: Hadston
locations.description: Reivers stole 3 horses from here in 1589.

locations.name: Haggerston
locations.description: A mixed gang of reivers stole 35 cattle and injured 4 men in peril of death, after smashing their doors down with axes in 1596. In another raid that year, 16 oxen, 9 horses and a dog were taken.

locations.name: Hailes
locations.description: The Taits and Pringles stole cattle here in 1498. The Earl of Angus attacked it in 1524.

locations.name: Halgreen Priory
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1542 and 1544.

locations.name: Halliday Hill Farm
locations.description: Some men scourged a naked woman with a bridle until she bled and cut the backs of her cattle in 1564.

locations.name: Hallrule
locations.description: The village and tower here were burnt by the English in 1523 and by the Armstrongs in1544.

locations.name: Halltree
locations.description: The Dalgliesh family raided this place in 1510.

locations.name: Halmyre Mains
locations.description: The Flemings stole 30 cattle here  in 1545.

locations.name: Haltwhistle
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1311. Fingerless Will Nixon and the Elliots burnt it in 1517.

locations.name: Harbottle
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1174, 1296, 1311 and 1318. Scottish reivers stole140 cattle from here in 1584, over 100 in 1587 and another 60 in 1588. The place was also raided by a mixed Scottish-English gang in 1595.

locations.name: Harcarse Hill Farm
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1482.

locations.name: Harehead Farms
locations.description: Reivers took 200 sheep, 40 oxen and cows from here in 1493.

locations.name: Harelaw
locations.description: The Kerrs burnt this place in 1570.

locations.name: Hartlepool
locations.description: Scottish forces attacked this place in 1312, 1315, 1322 and 1335.

locations.name: Harwood
locations.description: The Turnbulls stole 200 cows, 600 sheep and 30 horses from here in 1606.

locations.name: Hassendean
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1545.

locations.name: Hassington Mains
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1523.

locations.name: Haughton
locations.description: Scottish reivers stole 9 horses and £40 in 1541. And another 30 cattle in 1587

locations.name: Hawick
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1418, 1544 and 1570.

locations.name: Hawthornden Castle
locations.description: English forces attacked this place in 1544 and 1547.

locations.name: Haydon Bridge
locations.description: Kinmont Willie Armstrong houses burnt 4 houses here in 1587. The reivers stole everything they could find, including children's clothes, shrouds, pots and pans and a doorframe.

locations.name: Hayhope Farmhouse
locations.description: English forces destroyed this place in 1545.  Reivers also stole 40 ewes from here in 1596.

locations.name: Hayton
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1297. Reivers stole 12 horses from here in 1596. The Grahams robbed this place in 1600.

locations.name: Hazel Gill
locations.description: A gang of Nixons and Elliots stole over 90 beasts here in 1595.

locations.name: Hazlerigg
locations.description: Reivers stole 4 cattle and a dog from here in 1588.

locations.name: Heathery Burn
locations.description: Scottish reivers raided this place in 1587 and 1588.

locations.name: Heavyside
locations.description: English forces destroyed this place in 1544.

locations.name: Hedgeley
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1297. Scottish reivers raided it in 1588.

locations.description: Robert and Henry Douglas of Heiton were convicted of stealing 3 oxen from Sir William Colville of Synlaws in 1502. Sir William was murdered later that year. The English burnt the place in 1522 and 1545. Davidsons raided Heiton in 1597 and left a man “deadly hurt.”

locations.name: Hepburn
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1297 and 1383. Scottish reivers stole 44 sheep in 1587.

locations.name: Herdmanston
locations.description: English reivers raided this place in 1502, with the help of the Scotts.

locations.name: Hesket Newmarket
locations.description: The Grahams robbed this place in 1600.

locations.name: Hethersgill
locations.description: Reivers stole 40 cattle here in 1584.

locations.name: Hethpool
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1297. The Elliots stole about 20 animals and a huge list of weapons, clothes and other posessions in 1590. The town was raided in broad daylight by Carrs, Youngs and Burnes in 1596. They stole 40 cattle and came back a few days later for another 46.

locations.name: Hexham
locations.description: Scottish forces attacked this place in 1138, 1296, 1297, 1312, 1346, 1378 and 1385. The chronicler Richard of Hexham called the 1138 attackers "an execrable army, savager than any race of heathen yielding honour to neither God nor man" and claimed that they "harried the whole province and slaughtered everywhere folk of either sex, of every age and condition, destroying, pillaging and burning the villages, churches and houses". Fingerless Will Nixon and the Elliots also burnt the town in 1517.

locations.name: Highfield
locations.description: Scottish reivers stole 60 beasts from the Widow Milbourne, then fought the locals.

locations.name: High Hesket
locations.description: Kinmont Willie Armstrong rode his last raid here, in 1602.

locations.name: High Newton-by-the-Sea
locations.description: Scottish forces destroyed this place in 1383.

locations.name: Hoddom Castle
locations.description: The Armstrongs raided this place in 1502. Regent Moray besieged it in 1569 and English forces blew it up in 1570.

locations.name: Holm
locations.description: Brades Jock stole over 50 cattle from here in 1596/7.

locations.name: Holme Cultram
locations.description: Scottish forces sacked the abbey here in 1216. The Douglases also robbed it in 1319 and 1322. The Armstrongs raided 6 homes in 1592 and stole 24 beasts.

locations.name: Holmes
locations.description: The Lisle gang burnt houses near here in 1527.

locations.name: Holy Island
locations.description: Scots raided this place in 1061 and 1380.

locations.name: Holystone
locations.description: Scottish forces raided this place in 1311.

locations.name: Hopecarton Burn
locations.description: The Flemings stole the Tweedys’ wood here, in 1543 (during their long feud).

locations.name: Hoprig
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1523. English reivers raided it in 1596.

locations.name: Hornshole
locations.description: The young men of Hawick routed an English army from Hexham here and captured their flag in 1514

locations.name: Horsley
locations.description: Scottish reivers took almost 70 beasts from here between 1587-1590.

locations.name: Horsleyhill
locations.description: The Humes stole 40 sheep here in 1596.

locations.name: Hoselaw
locations.description: The Davidsons stole 18 cattle here in 1596.

locations.name: Houghton
locations.description: Reivers raided this place in 1541.

locations.name: Howden
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1545

locations.name: Howgill
locations.description: Reivers stole a horse here in 1600.

locations.name: Hownam
locations.description: Reivers stole 100 sheep from here in 1596 and 50 from Hownam Grange. The Pringles of Hownam stole also stole 2 horses from Sir Robert Carey that year.

locations.name: Hownam Grange
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1544 and 1545.

locations.name: Hownam Kirk
locations.description: The Davidsons of Hownam Kirk stole 27 sheep from England in 1587.

locations.name: Hownam Mains
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1544 and 1545.

locations.description: The Turnbulls raided this place in 1494 . The Armstrongs burnt it in 1535 (they were later hanged). English forces burnt the tower in 1543.

locations.name: Howtel
locations.description: Scottish reivers raided this place in 1602.

locations.name: Huldie Cottage
locations.description: English forces burnt a tower here in 1487.

locations.name: Humbleton
locations.description: John Reveley of Humbleton went reiving in Scotland in 1596.

locations.name: Hume Castle
locations.description: This castle was confiscated by Lord Albany in 1515, as punishment for the treachery of its owner Lord Home. The Homes then recaptured it, razed the walls and dammed the well. The town was burnt in 1544, up to the castle gates. It was captured by the English in 1547, then the Humes retook it in the night, in 1548. It was besieged again in 1549 and 1570.

locations.name: Hundalee
locations.description: English reivers raided this place with Scottish help in 1498 and 1502. English forces burnt this place in 1545.

locations.name: Hutton
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1482 and 1542.

locations.name: Hutton Mill
locations.description: Scottish forces cast down the mill in 1535.

locations.name: Ilderton
locations.description: Scottish reivers stole 120 animals and wounded 4 men in 1587.

locations.name: Inglewood
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1297, 1380, 1385 and 1388. The Grahams raided it in 1600.

locations.name: Ingram
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1385. Scottish reivers took the lead off the church roof in 1587, then stole 30 cattle in 1588.

locations.name: Innerleithen
locations.description: The Turnbulls stole cattle and other goods from here in 1494 and 1498. The Taits robbed the church in 1494.

locations.name: Innerwick Castle
locations.description: English forces burnt the castle in 1403, 1544 and 1547.

locations.name: Ireby
locations.description: Reivers raided this place in 1592.

locations.name: Irthington
locations.description: Scottish forces destroyed this place in 1296 and 1375. Scottish reivers raided here in 1600 and stole 120 animals, while mutilating several people.

locations.name: Irvine
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1513.

locations.name: Irvine Burn
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1513.

locations.name: Jedburgh
locations.description: English forces attacked this place many times, including 1296, 1297, 1312, 1320, 1346, 1409, 1410, 1416, 1464, 1482, 1523, 1544, 1545, 1547 and 1548. The abbey was burnt in many of these raids. The Kerrs and Olivers also attacked the town.

locations.name: Jed Forest
locations.description: Reivers killed Thomas Henrison here in 1493 and stole 5 ewes. The Hamiltons raided the Kerrs here in 1520.

locations.name: Kelloe
locations.description: English forces burnt his place in 1482.

locations.name: Kelso
locations.description: Scottish forces tried to destroy the bridge here in 1332 but were repelled. English forces burnt the town in 1522, 1523, 1542, 1544, 1545, 1546 and 1547, with the abbey burnt in most of these.

locations.name: Kemplee
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1297.

locations.name: Kendal
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1322.

locations.name: Kershope
locations.description: David Turnbull stole sheep here from here in 1494.

locations.name: Kilham
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1385. Various reivers took almost 50 beasts in 1596-97.

locations.name: Kimmerghame
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1482.

locations.name: King Water
locations.description: Reivers stole 100 beasts here in 1596.

locations.name: Kinmont Tower
locations.description: 300 English soldiers attacked the tower in 1600.

locations.description: The Grahams stole 9 cattle from here in 1592.

locations.name: Kirkby Thore
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1388.

locations.name: Kirkcudbright
locations.description: English forces besieged the town in 1547. They stole over 2,000 beasts in the process.

locations.name: Kirkharle
locations.description: William Loraine of Kirkharle stole 2 mares from Scotland in 1596.

locations.name: Kirkhaugh
locations.description: Scottish reivers took 50 beasts from here in 1589.

locations.name: Kirkheaton
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1388-89.

locations.name: Kirkhill
locations.description: Willie Johnstone of Kirkhill stole a horse at Gretna in 1592, sparking a chain of feuding that cost hundreds of lives.

locations.name: Kirkland
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1544.

locations.name: Kirklinton
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1297.

locations.name: Kirkmichael
locations.description: The Grahams burnt this place in 1557, with Scottish help.

locations.name: Kirknewton
locations.description: Scottish reivers raided this place in 1602.

locations.name: Kirkoswald
locations.description: Scottish forces attacked this place in 1314. Reivers raided it in 1592.

locations.name: Kirkpatrick-Fleming
locations.description: Reivers stole 11 beasts here in 1592. Also the authorities were attacked with stones and spears here in 1603, while trying to apprehend the Grahams.

locations.name: Kirk Yetholm
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1544 and 1545. The Halls stole 15 horses here in 1596.

locations.name: Knaresborough
locations.description: Scottish forces attacked this place in 1318.

locations.name: Ladykirk
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1542.

locations.name: Lag
locations.description: A gang of Griers and Bells burnt this place in 1532, stealing goods worth 500 Marks and wounding a servant to peril of life. The Jonstones raided it in 1585, during a spree which cost 18 lives.

locations.name: Lamberton
locations.description: English forces destroyed this place in 1544 and 1548.

locations.name: Lambley
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt the nunnery here in 1296.

locations.name: Lammermuir Hills
locations.description: The Olivers stole cattle from the Humes of Lammermuir in 1502, as part of a yearlong spree. Later that year, they were all sentenced to death.

locations.name: Lampert
locations.description: Reivers used this as a regular route, according to Thomas Musgrave in the 1570s.

locations.name: Lancaster
locations.description: Scottish forces attacked this place in 1322

locations.name: Lanercost Priory
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt the priory burnt 5 times: in 1280, 1296, 1297, 1311 and 1346

locations.name: Langholm
locations.description: English forces sacked this place in 1513, 1516. The Earl of Angus stole 4,000 beasts here in 1524. English forces captured the tower in 1544, only for Scots to recapture it in 1547. Scottish reivers burnt the town in 1581 and the Maxwells attacked it in 1585.

locations.name: Langley Park
locations.description: David Bruce’s Scottish army destroyed the manor house here in 1346. A castle was built as a result, in 1350.

locations.name: Langton
locations.description: This place was burnt by the Olivers in 1502 and by English forces in 1523 and 1558.

locations.name: Lanton
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1513 and 1545.

locations.name: Lauder
locations.description: A 1504 charter acknowledged that the town had suffered greatly from war, assaults and fire. The town was burnt again in 1545 and then held by the English 1547-1550. The Humes burnt people’s crops and barns here in 1561.

locations.name: Larriston
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1544.

locations.name: Lazonby
locations.description: Reivers stole 300 sheep from here in 1592.

locations.name: Learmouth
locations.description: Scottish forces attacked this place in 1523. The Pringles and Davidsons stole 14 cattle here in 1596. The Humes stole 5 bolls of malt the same year.

locations.name: Leith
locations.description: English forces sacked the port in 1296, 1384, 1481, 1544 (they took goods worth £10,000) and 1547. They also besieged it in 1560.

locations.name: Leitholm
locations.description: English forces burnt the tower here in 1545. Reivers raided this place in 1596.

locations.name: Lemmington Hall

locations.name: Lochwood
locations.description: 400 Maxwells and Armstrongs burnt over 80 houses here in 1585. They also burnt the castle "so that Lady Johnstone might have a light to put on her hood."

locations.name: Lochwood Castle

locations.name: Mitford Castle

locations.name: Morton Castle

locations.name: Twizel
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1545. The Taits stole 8 oxen here in 1596.

locations.name: Twizel Hill
locations.description: The Davidsons raided Lady Selby’s house and stole 20 beasts, while mortally wounding a man.

locations.name: Tynedale
locations.description: The Armstrongs burnt many farms in 1583 and 1584 and stole over 2,000 beasts. Reivers also stole over 3,000 beasts from here in 1593 and 230 beasts in 1598.

locations.name: Tynemouth
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1388-89.

locations.name: Uldale
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1297. Reivers robbed it in 1592.

locations.name: Upsettlington
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1542.

locations.name: Wallsend
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1388-89.

locations.name: Wall Tower
locations.description: English forces destroyed this place in 1487.

locations.name: Walton
locations.description: Reivers stole 80 cattle, 20 horse and goods worth £200 in 1596.

locations.name: Wampool
locations.description: The Grahams robbed this place in 1600.

locations.name: Warden
locations.description: Scottish forces stole over 30 beasts here in 1588 and another 50 in 1590.

locations.name: Wark
locations.description: Scottish forces attacked the town in 1138, 1139, 1296, 1318, 1342, 1383, 1385, 1399, 1419, 1513, 1521, 1523 and 1557. King John’s army also burnt the town in 1216 after the people had switched to pay homage to the Scottish king. The Davidsons and Youngs stole 6 cattle in 1596.

locations.name: Warkworth
locations.description: Scottish forces attacked this place in 1174 and 1448.

locations.name: Warwick-on-Eden
locations.description: The Armstrongs raided this place in 1601.

locations.name: Watcarrick
locations.description: Sir Walter Scott of Buccleugh and 500 men burnt down a door here in 1596 and took a horse and goods worth £400.

locations.name: Wedderburn Castle
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1522, 1523 and 1545.

locations.name: Wedderlie House
locations.description: A gang of Edgars from Wedderlie were accused of raiding Berwick in 1561, with jacks, swords, steel bonnets, dags and culverins. They were acquitted and various Swintons, Redpaths called to court.

locations.name: Wensleydale
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1316.

locations.name: West Fleetham
locations.description: Reivers stole 20 cattle from here in 1596.

locations.name: West Lilburn
locations.description: Scottish reivers took 10 cattle from a byre here in 1596.

locations.name: Westlinton
locations.description: The Grahams of Westlinton took 30 cattle from Annan in 1597.

locations.name: West Linton
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1545.

locations.name: Westnewton
locations.description: Scottish reivers raided this place in 1588. James Davidson’s gang stole over 30 beasts from here in 1595-96.

locations.name: West Woodburn
locations.description: The Youngs raided Raphe Selby’s tower here in 1596 and stole 3 geldings. The same man lost 80 sheep in anothrer raid that year.

locations.name: Wetheral
locations.description: The Grahams robbed this place in 1600.

locations.name: Whalton
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1388-89.

locations.name: Whitehill Farm
locations.description: The Armstrongs and Willie Kang burnt 6 houses here and stole goods worth £200 in 1596.

locations.name: Whitehope
locations.description: The Scotts raided this place in 1494.

locations.name: Whitekirk
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1544.

locations.name: Whitelaw
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1482.

locations.name: Whitmuir
locations.description: Reivers robbed this place in 1494.

locations.name: Whitslaid
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1455 and the Armstrongs burnt it in 1502.

locations.name: Whitsome
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1482.

locations.name: Whitton
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1523 and pulled the tower down. They also destroyed Whitton, Over Whitton and Nether Whitton in 1545. The Pringles stole a horse here in 1588.

locations.name: Widdrington
locations.description: On their way homeward from raiding Newcastle gaol in 1527, the Lisle gang raided Sir William Ellerker's park at Widdrington, taking 20 horses.

locations.name: Willington
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1388-89.

locations.name: Winkston Hill Farm
locations.description: The Tweedys mutilated cattle here 1621, for grazing on their land.

locations.name: Whittingham
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1385.

locations.name: Whittington
locations.description: Scottish forces destroyed this place in 1322.

locations.name: Wideopen
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1545.

locations.name: Wigton
locations.description: Scottish reivers stole almost 100 beasts from here in 1592.

locations.name: Wigtown
locations.description: William Graham and others robbed the Bishop of Galloway of silver cups and oxen here in 1513.

locations.name: Wingates
locations.description: The Elliots once stole 100 cattle and 4 horses here, burning 5 houses.

locations.name: Winton Castle
locations.description: English forces destroyed this place in 1544 and seized it in 1548.

locations.name: Wooden Farm (Northumberland)
locations.description: The Lisle gang plundered a house of 465 8d in 1527.

locations.name: Wooden Farm (Roxburghshire)
locations.description: English forces burnt this place in 1545.

locations.name: Woodhill Hall
locations.description: Scottish reivers took over 30 beasts here in 1589.

locations.name: Woodside
locations.description: The Scotts burnt houses here in 1587

locations.name: Wooler
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1385.

locations.name: Wooperton
locations.description: The Kerrs raided this place twice in 1587 with 10 horses and 8 cattle stolen, plus a man injured to the peril of his life.

locations.name: Workington
locations.description: The Curwens launched a daring raid from here in 1547 - stealing the gates of Caerlaverock castle and sailing back to Workington with them.

locations.name: Wrae
locations.description: The Flemings burnt this Tweedie stronghold in 1543.

locations.name: Wragmire
locations.description: The Grahams robbed this place in 1600.

locations.name: Wylam
locations.description: Scottish forces destroyed this place in 1297.

locations.name: Wyliecleugh
locations.description: English forces destroyed this place in 1544.

locations.name: Yearle
locations.description: Reivers stole 180 sheep here in 1596.

locations.name: Yeavering
locations.description: Scottish forces burnt this place in 1297.

locations.name: Yester Estate
locations.description: Reivers stole 100 sheep from here in 1529.

locations.name: Yester Fells
locations.description: Reivers stole 100 sheep from here in 1529.

locations.name: Yetholm
locations.description: English forces destroyed this place in 1482, 1523 and 1545.

locations.name: Aldin Grange
locations.description: King David II of Scotland was captured here in 1346, after the Battle of Neville’s Cross. Legend has it that his reflection was spotted by English soldiers as he hid under the bridge. He was held prisoner in England for 11 years.

locations.name: Allerwash
locations.description: Scottish reivers took a man for ransom here, in 1589.

locations.name: Alnwick
locations.description: 4 reivers escaped from jail here in 1523.

locations.name: Alnwick Castle
locations.description: King William the Lion was captured here in 1174 and held for ransom. The castle was often used to imprison reivers too - although they often escaped (Including a major break-out in 1523).

locations.name: Ancrum Moor
locations.description: Scottish forces took around 1,000 English prisoners here in 1545.

locations.name: Annan
locations.description: English soldiers took 72 prisoners from here in 1547. English reivers took 16 prisoners in 1592 and another 24 in 1597.

locations.name: Appleby
locations.description: By 1540, the castle was in a poor state but was used for keeping prisoners.

locations.name: Aydon Castle
locations.description: The owner of Aydon Castle was captured at the Battle of Bannockburn and held for a 500 Mark ransom.

locations.name: Ayton
locations.description: Patrick Home of Ayton was kidnapped by the garrison of Berwick, in 1544.

locations.name: Baileyhead
locations.description: Lancie Armstrong took 40 men prisoner here in 1580.

locations.name: Bamburgh Castle
locations.description: King David II of Scotland was held prisoner here in 1346.

locations.name: Barrow Burn
locations.description: Scottish reivers took 20 prisoners in 1584.

locations.name: Bass Rock
locations.description: Various prisoners were kept on the rock from the 1400s to 1690s.

locations.name: Berwick port
locations.description: The Scots agreed to pay a 4,300 Mark ransom for the release of a Flemish pirate, who had fought for them in 1333. But when they discovered he had betrayed them, they reneged on the deal and killed his son for good measure.

locations.name: Berwick-upon-Tweed
locations.description: Robert the Bruce's sister was kept in a cage on the town walls here. The Scots agreed to pay an emormous ransom of 100,000 Merks for the return of David II here in 1357. There was also a notorious prison here, known as "Haddock's Hole". In 1601, it was described as being "very loathsome", with the inmates likely to die.

locations.name: Bewcastle
locations.description: The Armstrongs took 30 prisoners from here in 1599 (after killing 3 men, following a day of “football and hard drinking”).

locations.name: Birkshaw
locations.description: Scottish reivers took 18 prisoners here in 1529.

locations.name: Blackadder
locations.description: The Humes imprisoned the two daughters of Andrew Blackadder here in the early 1500s, until they were old enough to marry their sons.

locations.name: Blackness Castle
locations.description: This castle was used as a prison for high-status inmates, including reivers. These included the Border warlord Wicked Wat Scott, who was imprisoned here after the Battle of Skirmish Hill in 1526 and 2 Turnbulls in 1531.

locations.name: Blennerhasset
locations.description: Reivers took 46 prisoners (many hurt) from here in 1592.

locations.name: Bonjedward
locations.description: The Laird of Bonjedward was taken prisoner by English forces in 1598.

locations.name: Brampton
locations.description: Scottish reivers took 30 prisoners here in 1601.

locations.name: Buccleuch
locations.description: Scott of Buccleuch was kidnapped by Sim 'the Laird' in 1530 (he seems to have kidnapped Sim himself, that same year, in a tit-for-tat feud).

locations.name: Burgh by Sands
locations.description: Reivers took 21 men and 2 boys prisoner here in 1592.

locations.name: Caerlaverock Castle
locations.description: There was a pit-prison in the Murdoch Tower.

locations.name: Cardoness Castle
locations.description: There was a 2-storey pit-prison here.

locations.name: Carham
locations.description: Sir John Lilburn was captured by the Scots here in 1377.

locations.name: Carlisle Castle
locations.description: Countless reivers were kept prisoner here - and many escaped. Most famously, Kinmont Willie Armstrong who was sprung by the Bold Buccleuch and 80 men in 1596.

locations.name: Cartington
locations.description: Reivers took 3 men prisoner here in 1589.

locations.name: Caulside
locations.description: Christopher Musgrave took about 40 prisoners near here in 1585.

locations.name: Cessford Castle
locations.description: This castle had a pit prison that could only be reached by a hatch in the floor above.

locations.name: Chillingham Castle
locations.description: There was a notorious dungeon here - now a major tourist attraction.

locations.name: Chipchase Castle
locations.description: Sir John Heron of Chipchase was captured and imprisoned by the Scots, while he conducted a raid in 1542.

locations.name: Chirnside
locations.description: English forces took prisoners here in 1558.

locations.name: Clennell
locations.description: Scottish reivers took “sundry prisoners” for ransom here, in 1587.

locations.name: Coldingham
locations.description: English monks here were implicated in many crimes including the kidnap of the Scottish monk Adam Crail, prompting the Scots to expel them in 1378.

locations.name: Coldstream
locations.description: Lord Hume captured the Chief Herald here and held him to ransom in 1516 (in attempt to free his own mother who was being held prisoner in Dunbar).

locations.name: Corby
locations.description: The Grahams kidnapped the 8-year-old son of the sheriff, to force the release of their kinsman in 1600.

locations.name: Cotehill
locations.description: The Grahams took 7 men prisoner here in 1602.

locations.name: Craigmillar Castle
locations.description: King James III imprisoned his brother here in 1477, accusing him of witchcraft and conspiracy.

locations.name: Crawford
locations.description: The Bells and Armstrongs took 12 men prisoner here, in 1585.

locations.name: Dalhousie Castle
locations.description: Sir Alexander Ramsay of Dalhousie was kidnapped and taken to Hermitage Castle in the Borders, where he starved to death.

locations.name: Dalpeddar
locations.description: Robert Crichton of Sanquhar Castle kidnapped, raped and murdered Marion of Dalpreddar in 1590.

locations.name: Davyshiel
locations.description: Scottish reivers took 13 prisoners here in 1587 and another man in 1589.

locations.name: Dirleton Castle
locations.description: The castle had a prison for high status inmates - and a foul pit for the lower classes.

locations.name: Donkleywood
locations.description: The Scotts took several men prisoner, while burning the village in 1596.

locations.name: Drumcoltran Tower
locations.description: George Maxwell of Drumcoltran was one of many Maxwells taken prisoner by the Johnstones in 1593.

locations.name: Drumelzier
locations.description: The Tweedies took 3 prisoners here in 1524. They also kidnapped the Master of Fleming, after murdering his father,

locations.name: Drumlanrig Castle
locations.description: The Douglases took about 400 English prisoners near here in 1548.

locations.name: Dryhope Tower
locations.description: The English Deputy Warden, Humphrey Musgrave captured the notorious Dick Armstrong of Dryhope and 3 others here in 1584.

locations.name: Dumfries
locations.description: Many reivers were imprisoned in the tolbooth here.

locations.name: Dunbar
locations.description: Over 130 Scots were taken prisoner after the battle here in 1296. Lord Home's mother was imprisoned here in 1516, causing him to raid the castle.

locations.name: Durham
locations.description: Scottish reivers took prisoners near here in 1595.

locations.name: Eckford
locations.description: English forces took 40 prisoners here in 1544.

locations.name: Eckford Tower
locations.description: Sir Roger de Mowbray was involved in a plot to kill Robert the Bruce. He was captured in 1320 and died in prison while awaiting trial.

locations.name: Edinburgh Castle
locations.description: Many reivers were imprisoned here - and many also escaped, including Adam Scott of Tushielaw in 1505, 'Wicked' Watt Scott in 1524 and some Jardines in 1584.

locations.name: Edrington
locations.description: Ninian Trotter kidnapped Ralph Cook here in 1540, when Cook brought his corn to the mill.

locations.name: Elsdon
locations.description: William Coxon was captured here in 1523. 400 people were taken prisoner by the Armstrongs and Elliots in 1586.

locations.name: Eslington
locations.description: The Kerrs took prisoners here in 1587 and 1596.

locations.name: Etal
locations.description: English forces took 61 Scottish prisoners here in 1523

locations.name: Ettrick Forest
locations.description: Adam Scott and Thomas Dalgliesh were kidnapped by the Maxwells here in 1581.

locations.name: Fairnington
locations.description: English forces took hundreds of prisoners here in 1549.

locations.name: Falstone
locations.description: Roger Spence was kidnapped and taken to Scotland around 1371.

locations.name: Fenton
locations.description: Scottish forces captured 100 men here in 1558.

locations.name: Ferniehirst Castle
locations.description: Dand Kerr of Ferniehirst was taken prisoner by the English in 1523.

locations.name: Flodden
locations.description: The English took 'divers prisoners' after the battle here in 1513, but some of their own Borderers delivered them back to the Scots, much to the outrage of the authorities.

locations.name: Ford Castle
locations.description: Sir William Heron of Ford Castle was held hostage by the Scots in 1513.

locations.name: Gilsland
locations.description: Scottish reivers took over 60 prisoners here in 1596.

locations.name: Girsonfield
locations.description: Gilbert de Umfraville kidnapped 2 Douglases in 1267. Scottish reivers took 10 men for ransom in 1587.

locations.name: Glasson
locations.description: 300 Scottish reivers broke down doors and kidnapped 21 men and 2 boys here in 1592/3.

locations.name: Glengelt
locations.description: English forces took many prisoners here in 1544.

locations.name: Gosforth
locations.description: The Lisles took 27 prisoners from the High St in 1527 and ransomed 20 of them, before taking 7 of them to Scotland to be kept as slaves.

locations.name: Greenhead
locations.description: The Laird of Greenhead was captured by the English, while raiding in 1597.

locations.name: Hadden Rig
locations.description: English forces took over 600 Scottish prisoners here, in 1542.

locations.name: Haddington
locations.description: Various prisoners were taken during the Siege of Haddington 1548-49, including the Englishman Nicholas Gaynesford, who was ransomed for £800.

locations.name: Hailes Castle
locations.description: The castle contains 2 pit-prisons.

locations.name: Halidon Hill Battlefield
locations.description: Patrick de Graham of Lovat was one of many Scottish prisoners taken after the battle of Halidon Hill in 1333.

locations.name: Halmyre Mains
locations.description: The Flemings kidnapped 6 men here in 1545.

locations.name: Haltwhistle
locations.description: The Armstrongs took prisoners here in 1599.

locations.name: Harbottle
locations.description: Sir William Douglas was kidnapped and imprisoned here in 1267.

locations.name: Harelaw
locations.description: The Armstrongs of Harelaw kidnapped 4 Hendersons in 1601, killing the eldest of them, to encourage the family to pay up.

locations.name: Haughton Castle
locations.description: The reiver Archie Armstrong was kept prisoner here - the owners forgot about him and he starved to death.

locations.name: Hawick
locations.description: Sir Alexander Ramsay was kidnapped here in 1342. He was dragged from church in chains, bleeding, to Hermitage Castle, where he starved to death. Lord Ruthven also captured many Kerrs here in 1572.

locations.name: Hedgehope
locations.description: The Croziers kidnapped over 20 people here in 1544.

locations.name: Hell Beck
locations.description: Queen Elizabeth's forces took 200 prisoners here in 1570.

locations.name: Hepple
locations.description: Sir Robert Ogle of Hepple was captured by Scots in a raid here and ransomed for 750 Marks.

locations.name: Hermitage Castle
locations.description: Sir Alexander Ramsay was held prisoner here in 1342 - and starved to death. Two of Lord Dacre's men were captured and held here in 1528. The Earl of Bothwell captured many Elliots and kept them prisoner here in 1566. The inmates subsequently rebelled and took over the castle.

locations.name: Hexham
locations.description: The Earl of Northumberland took hostages here in 1535, in return for good behaviour. Liddesdale reivers kidnapped peopler here in 1545. The Elliots took 20 prisoners here in 1583.

locations.name: Hexham Old Gaol
locations.description: This is the oldest prison in England, built specially to house reivers. It was the scene of many breaks outs, including a mass escape of Armstrongs, Dodds and Charltons in 1538.

locations.name: Holme Cultram
locations.description: The Armstrongs kidnapped a man for ransom here in 1592.

locations.name: Holy Island
locations.description: 400 French mercenaries were captured here in 1462.

locations.name: Howpasley
locations.description: Davie 'the Lady' of Howpasley was captured in 1531 and taken to Edinburgh Castle.

locations.name: Humbleton
locations.description: English forces took many prisoners here after the battle of 1402. The English released them the following year, when it was clear they could not obtain a ransom, and many of the Scots expressed their gratitude by joining the English in their war against the Welsh.

locations.name: Irthington
locations.description: Scottish reivers took prisoners here in 1600.

locations.name: Jedburgh
locations.description: A shoemaker was kidnapped here and taken to England in 1493. English forces took 24 hostages here in 1544.

locations.name: Kelso
locations.description: Peter Nairne was charged with inducing several Englishmen to cross the border, with the aim of kidnapping them and klling them in 1601.

locations.name: Kershopefoot
locations.description: Kinmont Willie Armstrong was taken prisoner here in 1596, in violation of the Truce Day.

locations.name: Kilham
locations.description: Several Scottish reivers were taken prisoner here in 1597, while raiding the village. However, more of them came back at dawn, rescued their friends and killed 7 several locals.

locations.name: Kirkhaugh
locations.description: Scottish reivers took “sundry prisoners” from here in 1589.

locations.name: Kirkmichael
locations.description: The Douglases kidnapped a man here in 1610 and took him to Drumlanrig.

locations.name: Kirkudbright
locations.description: English forces took prisoners at the siege of 1547. In fact at least one local woman arranged for her husband to be taken for ransom, to spare him being killed.

locations.name: Lanercost Priory
locations.description: Scottish forces captured the prior for ransom, in 1385. They were still holding him in 1386.

locations.name: Langholm
locations.description: Scottish reivers took prisoners here in 1581.

locations.name: Lauder
locations.description: The Town Hall here stands on the site of a tolbooth which often housed imprisoned reivers. However it was burnt down in 1598, by a gang of Humes, who murdered an inmate in the process.

locations.name: Learmouth
locations.description: Scottish forces took prisoners here in 1523.

locations.name: Liddisdale
locations.description: The Earl of Angus captured 24 reivers here in 1527. The local reivers captured 40 English pursuers after a raid in 1528. The English took 18 prisoners here in 1586. They also took 60-80 men, women and children prisoner in 1596, stripping them and tying them “like dogs”. Up to 10 of the children died of cold, as a result.

locations.name: Linbriggs
locations.description: Scottish reivers took 20 prisoners here in 1589.

locations.name: Lochmaben Castle
locations.description: The owner of the castle, John Carruthers, was captured by the Johnstones here in 1454 and probably died in the dungeon.

locations.name: Lochwood Castle
locations.description: The Armstrongs helped the English to take 140 prisoners here in 1545. The Maxwells took 12 Johnstones prisoner in 1585.

locations.name: Lockerbie
locations.description: The Maxwells took prisoners here in 1585.

locations.name: Mangerton Tower
locations.description: Humphrey Musgrave kidnapped the Laird of Mangerton.

locations.name: Melrose
locations.description: The Croziers took 20 prisoners here in 1544.

locations.name: Milfield
locations.description: English forces took about 400 Scottish prisoners here, after Lord Home's disastrous raid of 1513.

locations.name: Mitford Castle
locations.description: Sir Gilbert Middleton used this place as a base for kidnappings in 1315-1317. His victims included the Bishop of Durham, his brother and 2 Italian cardinals. Middleton was eventually taken to London and hung, drawn and quartered (the cardinals insisted on watching).

locations.name: Morpeth Castle
locations.description: The Swinburnes kidnapped a man from here in 1523.

locations.name: Muggleswick
locations.description: The parson was kidnapped by William Charlton in 1528. Their leader was later tracked down and slain.

locations.name: Muirhouselaw
locations.description: The Rutherfords kidnapped 4 men here in 1502, taking them to England where they were held for 3 months, before being released for a ransom.

locations.name: Neidpath Castle
locations.description: This castle contains a pit-prison that was only reachable via a hatch in the floor above.

locations.name: Nevilles Cross
locations.description: Many Scottish knights were taken prisoner here, after the Battle of Nevilles Cross in 1346 (King David II was taken at nearby Aldin Grange). A dispute later arose between the locals and Edward III about who had the right to the ransoms.

locations.name: Newby Bridge
locations.description: Scottish reivers took a man for ransom in 1592.

locations.name: Newcastle upon Tyne
locations.description: Reivers were often kept prisoner here. In 1527 a gang led by Sir William Lisle escaped and went on the rampage before being recaptured and executed.

locations.name: Newminster Abbey
locations.description: Scottish forces took the prior hostage in 1297.

locations.name: Niddrie
locations.description: Simon Preston and 50 men waylaid the Laird of Niddrie and prevented him from going to his home in 1495.

locations.name: Nisbet
locations.description: English forces took many prisoners here in 1355, only to kill them later. They also took prisoners (including at least 5 knights) here, after the battle in 1402.

locations.name: Norham
locations.description: The Constable of Norham castle was captured by the Scots in 1355 and taken to Scotland for 2 years. Prisoners were exchanged between Scotland and England in 1597, as a pledge for good behaviour.

locations.name: Oldhamstocks
locations.description: English forces took many prisoners between here and Ayton, in 1533.

locations.name: Orton
locations.description: The Armstrongs took a man prisoner for ransom here in 1592. The Grahams took prisoners in 1603.

locations.name: Otterburn
locations.description: Scottish forces took many prisoners after the battle in 1388, including the English hero Henry “Hotspur” Percy.

locations.name: Ottercops
locations.description: Hugh Fenwick kidnapped William Aynsley in 1523 and kept him here, for ransom.

locations.name: Peebles
locations.description: Lord Hay allowed 2 reivers to escape custody in 1530 and was relieved of his position as Sheriff of Peebles.

locations.name: Pinkie Cleugh
locations.description: English forces captured 1,500 prisoners here in 1547.

locations.name: Piperdean
locations.description: The English commander Sir Robert Ogle was captured here in 1435.

locations.name: Plenderleith
locations.description: English forces took prisoners here in 1598.

locations.name: Plumbland
locations.description: Two men were taken prisoner here in 1592.

locations.name: Ragpeth
locations.description: Scottish reivers kidnapped a man here  in 1596, and ransomed him for 42L “and some odd money.”

locations.name: Reaveley
locations.description: Scottish reivers took over 50 prisoners from here in 1587.

locations.name: Redesdale
locations.description: The Lisles kidnapped 2 men here in 1523.

locations.name: Redeswire
locations.description: Scottish reivers took English prisoners here after a truce day degenerated into fighting and murder in 1575.

locations.name: Reston
locations.description: English forces took 140 prisoners here in 1524.

locations.name: Richmond
locations.description: Scottish reivers took prisoners for ransom here in 1595.

locations.name: Rickergate
locations.description: Reivers took prisoners here in 1601.

locations.name: Rowanburn
locations.description: Kinmont Willie Armstrong was famously kidnapped here in 1596, in a flagrant breach of a Day of Truce. He later escaped from Carlisle Castle.

locations.name: Roxburgh Castle
locations.description: Robert the Bruce's sister Mary was suspended in a cage here, in 1306.

locations.name: Rushyford
locations.description: Sir Gilbert Middleton kidnapped the Bishop of Durham and 2 Italian Cardinals here in 1317. He was later taken to London and hanged drawn and quartered. The cardinals insisted on watching.

locations.name: Saltoun Castle
locations.description: 5 Scottish traitors were taken prisoner in 1548, after the siege of the caste.

locations.name: Scotby
locations.description: Scottish reivers took prisoners here in 1600 and 1601.

locations.name: Selkirk
locations.description: English forces took prisoners here in 1296.

locations.name: Sidwood
locations.description: Tristram Dodd was taken to Scotland as prisoner 1589.

locations.name: Smailholm Tower
locations.description: English forces took 200 prisoners from here in 1524.

locations.name: Solway Moss
locations.description: Over 1,000 Scottish prisoners were taken for ransom here in 1542, after the battle.

locations.name: Spott Burn
locations.description: English forces took over 100 Scottish prisoners after the Battle of Dunbar in 1296. They were all taken to England for ransom.

locations.name: Stobbs
locations.description: Scottish reivers took prisoners here in 1587.

locations.name: Swinburne Castle
locations.description: James Young was kept prisoner here in 1596. 200 armed Kerrs broke into the castle and released him.

locations.name: Tantallon Castle
locations.description: The dungeon here was described as a "hideous cavern, arched overhead, dank and dripping with an opening towards the sea."

locations.name: Tarras Moss
locations.description: English forces captured many reivers here (mostly Armstrongs) in 1597.

locations.name: Terregles
locations.description: The Grahams kidnapped 4 men for ransom here, in 1597.

locations.name: Teviothead
locations.description: Johnnie Armstrong was captured here before his execution in 1530.

locations.name: The Merse
locations.description: The Scots took several hundred English prisoners here in 1523, ambushing them as they conducted a series of raids.

locations.name: Thirlwall
locations.description: The Nixons and Crosers kidnapped a man here in 1528.

locations.name: Throphill
locations.description: The Lisle gang took 3 prisoners in 1527.

locations.name: Torthorwald Castle
locations.description: Lord Carlisle's grand-daughter (aged 6) was kidnapped by her uncle here in 1575, in an attempt to prevent her marrying a Douglas. She was later recovered in England and the marriage went ahead when she was 18.

locations.name: Torwoodlee Tower
locations.description: George Hoppringle of Torwoodlee captured Archibald Armstrong in 1530.

locations.name: Tourneyholme
locations.description: This place was often used for the exchange of Scottish and English prisoners.

locations.name: Troughend
locations.description: The Crosiers took 80 prisoners here in 1584.

locations.name: Tynedale
locations.description: Scottish reivers kidnapped 40 people here in 1525. The English authorities took 18 prisoners in 1533 (and sent them for hanging). Armstrongs took 30 prisoners here in 1583. Reivers from Jed Forest kidnapped a widow, her servants and children from here in 1596.

locations.name: Tynemouth
locations.description: A Scotsman was captured here in 1597, as he was on a mission to blow up Sir Robert Kerr.

locations.name: Upper Denton
locations.description: Reivers took 100 prisoners here in 1597.

locations.description: Scottish reivers were pursued here in 1590, only to capture 4 of their pursuers and ransom them (and their horses) for £23.

locations.description: The Lisle gang took 6 prisoners near here in 1527. The castle was also used to imprison reivers, including the notorious villain Jerry "Topping' Charlton.

locations.name: Widdrington

locations.name: Yeavering

locations.name: Allanton

locations.name: Bass Rock
locations.description: The prison here plays a key role in The Dance of Vipers.

locations.name: Berwick-upon-Tweed

locations.name: Birgham
locations.description: There is a brief mention in The Trail of Blood, of the priest's house being ransacked here.

locations.name: Black Rig

locations.name: Cheeklaw
locations.description: This is the home of Catherine Gray.

locations.name: Chirnside

locations.name: Clovenfords

locations.name: Cockburnspath
locations.description: Our heroes stop off here in The Dance of Vipers, as Margaret Tudor is ill.

locations.description: Coldstream features heavily in The Trail of Blood. Especially the old priory, which has left its mark in many of the street names here.

locations.name: Cornhill-on-Tweed
locations.description: This is the home of Cospatrick Dixon, in The Trail of Blood.

locations.name: Cranshaws

locations.name: Dalkeith
locations.description: Antoine and Turnbull pass through here in The Trail of Blood and are impressed by how bustling and industrious it is.

locations.name: Dunbar Castle

locations.name: Duns

locations.name: Ettrick Forest

locations.name: Fala
locations.description: There is a dramatic scene here, in The Dance of Vipers, as Will Baird's enemies close in on him.

locations.name: Fast Castle
locations.description: Tam Simpson (one of Antoine's men in The Trail of Blood) was previously a cook here, so takes over the kitchen duties at Black Rig. This later makes him a suspect for a poisoning.

locations.name: Fife
locations.description: One of the fugitives in The Dance of Vipers is said to come from here.

locations.description: The Battle of Flodden in 1513 forms the backdrop to my series and is mentioned throughout. It was a devastating defeat for Scotland, which left the country in a precarious state. On a more personal level, Turnbull lost his father and 2 brothers there.

locations.name: Fogo
locations.description: Turnbull's horse is named after this hamlet.

locations.name: Gainslaw
locations.description: Turnbull passes through here in The Trail of Blood.

locations.name: Hawick

locations.name: Hexham Old Gaol

locations.name: Innerwick

locations.name: Kelso

locations.name: Kincham Wood
locations.description: Antoine has a brush with death here, in The Trail of Blood.

locations.name: Langholm

locations.name: Lasswade

locations.name: Leith

locations.name: Leitholm

locations.name: Melrose

locations.name: Newark Castle

locations.name: Palace of Holyroodhouse

locations.name: Selkirk

locations.name: Tantallon Castle

locations.name: Tranent
